PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.
Bill presented by Mr Gibson.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Cooperation Control Bill I am introducing today seeks to establish a very clear fundamental principle as a foundation for Australia's defence links with other nations. It seeks to reinforce the primacy of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights as the basis for Australia's domestic and international policies and actions.

PARA.TAB: Australia has a very proud record of achievement of human rights both at home and abroad. We are widely perceived as good `international citizens' who have consistently pursued peace, freedom, democracy and observance of human rights for the whole period of our nationhood. Australians hold these principles very dearly and tens of thousands of our men and women have sacrificed their lives during the 20th century so other people around the world could enjoy the same rights and freedoms that we do.

The bill proposes that Australian defence forces should not engage in any cooperative arrangements with the armed forces of any nation which uses those forces as a deliberate instrument of state policy to deny basic human rights to its own people or people of another state.

The definitions contained in the bill are very clear and concise. Basic human rights are determined as those set out in the internationally accepted Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Defence cooperation is any exercise, training or exchange of information, technology or personnel.

I do not believe that we as a nation should work with the armed forces of another nation when they are used to suppress the very rights of people which our defence forces are established to protect. This bill does not seek to interfere in the internal operations of another nation; it purely keeps us at arms length from its abusive power.

The procedure to implement this principle is set out in the bill. A certificate would be issued by the Minister for Foreign Affairs giving a clearance to the Minister for Defence and the chief of the defence forces to participate in defence cooperation arrangements with a particular nation. This certificate would only be issued once the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, using its representatives in diplomatic posts in that nation, is satisfied that it is not a deliberate state policy to use its armed forces to suppress human rights.

This certificate would be a disallowable instrument thereby allowing scrutiny of the process by the parliament. The certificate can be reviewed at any time that it appears the policies of that nation have changed and can be revoked. There is a clause in the bill which would ensure that the operation of this process would not interfere in our nation's capacity to contribute to UN peacekeeping or defence operations.

I believe the majority of Australians support the principles behind this bill. They do not want to see our fine international record as a good world citizen corrupted through any defence links with nations that do not uphold basic human rights.

I reject the argument that through such defence links Australia is better able to influence the practices of those armed forces or to educate them towards protecting human rights. The use of armed forces to suppress rights and liberties is a policy of the particular government and it is therefore the governments of those nations we should pursue. This bill is a reasonable, concise and principled proposal which deserves the support of the House.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:

(1)takes note of the Queensland Council of Social Services report entitled Drawing the line on poverty which shows that Queensland is the most poverty-stricken State in Australia with 350000 people living in poverty; and
(2)calls on all Australian governments to address the issue of poverty and the growing gap between rich and poor in this country.

I am pleased to see the shadow minister for social security in the chamber because he raised aspects of this matter in a recent MPI. Poverty is alive and well in the sunshine state. As a Queenslander, that is something I say with not much pride. That is a statement of Peter Walsh, the director of the Queensland Council of Social Service and one of the principal authors of a recent report Drawing the line on poverty. The report gives us a disturbing insight into the raw statistics, the human face of poverty and the disadvantage being experienced in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: Over the last decade, Queensland has been the leading state in terms of economic growth, and industrial and business investment. However, not everyone has shared equally in that success. The report demonstrates that poverty and disadvantage are often hidden or marbled through the community. The report demonstrates that the social safety net is not working, despite the chest beating of the government and members opposite.

The report highlights this government's failure to adequately address the public housing and health needs of even the most needy in our community. The report demonstrates the growing dependence of welfare agencies on emergency relief funding at a time when the federal government is actually cutting back on such assistance. Far from the rhetoric of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about helping the battlers, this report demonstrates that, in reality, the government has ignored the battlers.

The report Drawing the line on poverty was conducted essentially in three parts: a breakdown of national socioeconomic statistics for Queensland based on ABS and 1991 census data; the 1994 survey of more than 300 church and community organisations throughout Queensland providing emergency assistance; and case studies of five diverse areas of Queensland where low income people relying on emergency relief were interviewed directly.

The main statistical findings of this report have already been highlighted in the media and in this parliament by the shadow minister, as I said. For the purpose of this debate, I would like to give a quick reminder to all those opposite of some of the key facts. Eighteen per cent, or almost one fifth, of the Queensland population live in poverty. The Queensland poverty rate is two per cent greater than the national average.

After housing costs are taken out, 350,000 Queenslanders are living below the poverty line. Of this, almost 137,000 are children living in families below the poverty line, which represents 26 per cent, or just over a quarter, of Queensland children. Elderly people have a before housing poverty rate of 27.2 per cent and 24.6 per cent, or almost a quarter, of young people under 25 years live in poverty. Two in three sole parents exist below the poverty line and the average weekly disposable income is lower in Queensland than in the other states.

These are the statistics. They are very revealing statistics. They are statistics which Queenslanders can take no pride in. While some of those opposite might dismiss these figures as being somewhat dated, let us remember that this is the most current data available. While, like those members opposite, I wait to see the results of the 1996 census, I will be the first to applaud if they are better. But if the trend in poverty follows the trend in unemployment along the Queensland coast then it will not be a pretty picture. Even so, let us take a look at the two other components of the report which are based on surveys conducted just last year, 1994, of low income people who are living below the poverty line.

Let us first look at emergency relief. The poverty research looks at who relies on—and why they do—emergency assistance to supplement their low incomes; that is, emergency relief provided by the Commonwealth and some states to church and community welfare organisations, like the Salvation Army, Lifeline, women's crisis centres, Aboriginal and Islander housing cooperatives, and so on. This is probably the most damning part of the poverty report. It demonstrates that the government's much heralded social wage or safety net is ineffectual for a great many battlers.

Declaring a single example of the failure of the government's social wage is a finding that, of 2,556 people surveyed between August and September 1994 who received emergency relief, 2,118 or 82.2 per cent of them received a government pension or benefit. I repeat: 82 per cent of people who received emergency aid in Queensland were already reliant on government benefit.

I would also highlight the plight of the other 18 per cent who do not rely on government benefits and who are the real battlers in the community. The government's insensitivity to this group was highlighted just yesterday in this House with the passing of a budget measure that increases the safety net for pharmaceutical benefits from $400 to $600. You might recall that not so many years ago it was $312. That means that you have to be twice as sick as you were five years ago to get the safety net. That also means that those people who are on fixed incomes, many of whom are in that 18 per cent category, would be suffering from that measure and would possibly be cutting back on their medicinal requirements.

I go back to the 82 per cent receiving government benefit. The biggest group demanding emergency assistance were the unemployed, making up 38 per cent of the total, followed by sole parents, making up 24 per cent. The survey also found that the majority of requests for emergency assistance were for basic living needs, including food, 23.1 per cent, and housing related costs, 23.8 per cent, which were cited as the two most common reasons. Requests for assistance for gas, electricity and water bills made up 22 per cent, with the biggest single reason for cash assistance coming from families with children. Medical expenses counted for seven per cent of requests, but again these mainly came from families with children—and that highlights the point I made earlier about the safety net.

The other revealing part of the poverty survey was the response of the welfare agency workers—those at the human coalface, if you like. Welfare workers regarded the severe shortage of public housing as one of the most critical issues impacting on the level of demand for emergency relief, in particular for young people and single parents.

In June of this year, in the city of Gladstone, in my electorate, Ray Chapman of the Careforce community housing scheme had 60 people on his waiting list. He reports getting, basically, two categories of people presenting themselves for housing assistance: single women with one child, and single people trying to subsist on government benefits. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Its very difficult to find accommodation for young single people—theyre discriminated against in many ways. It's pretty difficult to survive on $150 a week.
One of the more pertinent comments from a survey respondent was:

Emergency relief is and will continue to be income supplement unless the structural causation of disadvantage is addressed. Emergency relief is a misnomer and an inadequate substitute for Social Security equity.
I think that says it all. Agency workers themselves comment on the inadequacy of the existing levels of pensions and benefits.

PARA.TAB: While I recognise that emergency relief is largely a bandaid measure, I find it extraordinary that the Commonwealth is slashing this funding while it is doing nothing to rectify the situation of thousands of desperate people who rely on these handouts to survive. Total funding under the Commonwealth emergency relief program has been halved in the last three years, from $30.2 million in 1992-93 to $14.8 million in 1995-96.

This alone in my electorate of Hinkler has resulted in agencies having their funding cut from between 9.3 per cent and a massive 30 per cent. That is despite the fact that the Wide Bay-Burnett and Capricorn regions have the worst unemployment rates in Queensland and amongst the worst in the nation. In Wide Bay-Burnett, for instance, the unemployment rate is 13.6 per cent. In June this year, DEET figures revealed that the unemployed youth seeking full-time employment represented 41.5 per cent.
Not surprisingly, many of these organisations have reacted strongly to the latest cut in emergency aid. Kenneth Young, from the Bundaberg Housing Action Group, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Bundaberg people in desperate need of assistance will be disadvantaged by the decrease in funding allocations.
The Gladstone Salvation Army Captain David Pullen said:
. . . this will put our resources under greater strain . . . the shortfall of more than $2000 represented about 40 families the funds would have helped.
Cedric Williams, from the Gladstone Aboriginal and Islander Cooperative, said:
Many times our own staff have had to put their hands in their own pockets to meet the needs of people here, but the government doesn't recognise that.
(Time expired).

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this debate on poverty, and I certainly congratulate the Queensland Council of Social Service and the Sisters of Mercy who were sponsors of this research report. I believe it is very important to have a dialogue and a debate. There is a great deal of information on issues such as social inequality and there are many new studies.

PARA.TAB: The first thing we need to draw attention to is the fact that this is pretty rich coming from an opposition who, when they were last in government, saw the real value of pensions decrease by two per cent and the value of the social wage decrease by 17.5 per cent under the then Treasurer, who is now the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

In relation to the poverty survey that was referred to by my colleague the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), the important issue that we do have to recognise is that the ABS figures, on which much of the data is based, are six years old. Since 1990, the Commonwealth government has substantially increased the real value of social security and pensions. For example, the income of a single pensioner renting privately has increased from six per cent to 13 per cent above the Henderson poverty line. The income of a sole parent who has two children and is renting privately has increased from nine per cent below to two per cent above the Henderson poverty line. The income of an unemployed couple who have one child and are renting privately has increased from 11 per cent below to one per cent above the Henderson poverty line. So there has been a substantial change in income support measures from the Commonwealth to the group that the member for Hinkler is concerned about.

The other issue that I think we do have to understand is the nature of the measure on which the report is based. The Henderson poverty line was designed in the 1960s by Ronald Henderson. It is an all or nothing measure, which nominates a point on the income scale below which people are understood to be in poverty. Since that time, disposable income has risen much faster than inflation, so an income on the poverty line in 1990-91 bought one-fifth more goods and services than 20 years ago.

However, if you use the Henderson poverty line to measure poverty, you might assess that poverty has increased over the eighties by one-third. In using alternative measures, the poverty rate has in fact fallen by about seven per cent. I think this has been emphasised by the recent work done by Anne Harding at the University of Canberra's National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling. I want to quote from the excellent article by Deborah Hope in the Weekend Australian of 3-4 June, covering issues such as social inequality. Her article states:

SPEECH.PARA: According to Harding's estimate about 1.8 million Australians, including half a million children, are living below the poverty line—a tally significantly lower than the figure of 2.5 million of five years ago. Harding suggests one reason for this may be that social security payments have been improved in recent years to lift many welfare recipients on maximum benefits over the poverty threshold.

Indeed, I believe a number of our arrangements in the life and term of this government have contributed to the wellbeing of many families. One could point to the parenting allowance. All of these have been indexed. Indeed, yesterday the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) announced new increases in maternity allowance and pensions and the indexations from 20 September of this year so that single pensioners will receive $9.80 more per fortnight and each member of a pensioner or allowee couple will receive $8.20 more per fortnight. This means, for example, that the new parenting allowance, which was introduced only last month, will be increased by $8.20 to $280.20 per fortnight. The maternity allowance, which is equal to six weeks maximum parenting allowance, will be $840.60 when it is first paid next February.

PARA.TAB: We have made a definite and determined contribution to make sure that pensions and benefits are indexed according to the cost of living, which is something the Fraser government never did and caused this decrease in income support. Additional family payment and basic family payment, which goes to the battlers as well as to the social security beneficiaries, is also a very important part of the social wage component. So there are a number of ways in which this government has made a huge and definite contribution.

One of the important issues is the attack on unemployment in this term of government. It is obviously the greatest challenge to social inequality. It should be recorded that since March 1983 this Labor government has created two million jobs. Indeed, we came back into government in 1993 with a firm commitment from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to deal with issues such as long-term unemployment.

It is a very proud record that over the last two years employment growth has been outstanding, with 670,000 more Australians in jobs compared with 1993 figures and, particularly, a drop in the number of long-term unemployed people by 21 per cent. So, if you look at a range of information, you will see that the picture is much better than is being suggested by a number of opposition spokespersons. One of the reasons for this is the value of the social wage and non-cash payments. I refer once again to Hope's article, because she was actually looking at whether there is an underclass in this country. Page 14 states:

SPEECH.PARA: A review of the evidence, however, together with interviews with people living in disadvantaged areas on low incomes, suggest that although unemployment means inequality is increasing in Australia—
and there are many reasons for this inequality in terms of market incomes for people, and they relate to technological change and the structural changes in the nature of work and job categories—
there is no underclass, principally because our social safety net—including income support, assistance for low-income families, Medicare, housing, training programs and counselling . . . is working.

In relation to the housing issue in the Queensland poverty survey, it is important to recall that a great deal of the statistical data was collected just after the Goss Labor government had been installed. Effectively what you were looking at was a poverty situation that related very much to 30 years of neglect by the National Party government in Queensland. For example, the public housing stock is only 3.6 per cent of households. That is obviously a crucial test of poverty. Since 1988 the number of public dwellings in Queensland has increased by more than 60 per cent. So the Goss Labor government is moving to rectify that very low incidence of public housing, which of course is a major housing issue.

PARA.TAB: The other issue that is important to look at is who is benefiting from the Department of Social Security initiatives and our job creation programs. If we look at the figures that relate to December last year, we see those in the youth category who register as being out of work—a category referred to by the member for Hinkler—receive support for about 10 months. Indeed, the more difficult group is the people who are aged 45 years and older. Only 10 per cent of young people in the 18- to 24-year category have been out of work for more than a year.

It is a great challenge to meet those needs. Our youth training initiative is designed to meet the concerns and the needs of that group. I believe we are winning that war. I refer to the book of Travers and Richardson entitled Living decently: material wellbeing in Australia. It says that the present standards of living in Australia have never been equalled. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: This is true whether we look at real purchasing power per person . . . at standards of housing and extent of education, at the quality of medicine, the extent of support of people who have few resources of their own and at equality of opportunity.
An EPAC review indicated:

The paper notes that a 30 per cent overall rise in Australians' standard of living in the past 12 years, as well as social progress in childcare, Medicare, tax reform, training, compulsory superannuation and improved payments to low-income families in the eighties and nineties.
It also includes growth in jobs and wages and indicates employment growth and productivity gains are also helping. These are the very policies of a Labor government over 12 years. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wholeheartedly support the call of the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) for the growing gap between rich and poor in our country to be urgently addressed, because to date this government has had neither the political integrity to recognise the problem nor the political will to address it. No politician who takes the time to meet and talk with the people they represent has the luxury of believing, in the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), that `this is a golden age'.

PARA.TAB: While it is a golden age for some, for a large and growing number it is an age of financial struggle, despair and unrealised potential. The level of poverty in our country is simply unacceptable. The central conclusion of the Queensland Council of Social Service's report entitled Drawing the line on poverty is that poverty in Australia is not the condition of an isolated few.

While I recognise that the member for Hinkler's motion asks that the House specifically take note of this report and of poverty in Queensland, as a South Australian I am only too familiar with the fact that poverty is a national problem. As the situation in Queensland seems to indicate, the combination of federal and state Labor governments does not bode well for a state. South Australia has only recently emerged from the dark years of the Bannon Labor government. At the time that the Brown Liberal government took over office in South Australia our state debt was accelerating towards $9 billion. This debt is now being cut back, but the ultimate effect of Labor's economic mismanagement has been a level of poverty that we need not have had.

As I have said, poverty is a national problem. A study released earlier this year by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling at the University of Canberra estimated that 1.8 million Australians are living in poverty. Of this number, nearly 1.2 million were members of families with children—a chilling reminder of the failure of Labor to honour its 1987 election promise that `by 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty'. Australian society has been torn apart by the growth of poverty, as the gap between the rich and the poor grows wider. The sense of community, which has previously bound us together as a nation, must necessarily weaken.

A recently released study by Professor Bob Gregory investigated the polarisation of wealth and poverty in Australia. The findings of this study are alarming. Twenty years ago the average income of people in the bottom five per cent of Australian neighbourhoods was 60 per cent of that of people in the top five per cent of neighbourhoods. By 1991, those at the bottom were earning less than 40 per cent of the income earned by Australia's wealthy. Over the same period average household income in the top five per cent of neighbourhoods rose by 23 per cent. In stark contrast, those in the poorer five per cent of neighbourhoods found themselves surviving on an average household income that fell by 23 per cent.

Gregory found that employment levels between the neighbourhoods were also polarising. From the mid-1970s to 1991 the number of employed men as a proportion of the population dropped by 42 per cent in the bottom five per cent of neighbourhoods. This compares to a drop of 20 per cent in wealthier areas. This polarisation has been reinforced by trends in employment levels for women. In the 15 years prior to 1991, the level of employment among women living in the top half of Australian neighbourhoods increased by about 10 per cent. Over the same period it fell by a dramatic 40 per cent for women living in poorer areas.

Income inequity and poverty in Australia is entrenched and increasing. Surely there is no greater proof of the failure of economic management over the last 13 years than this. I would suggest that a good starting point from which to begin the task of reversing the trend towards income inequity would be for the government to at least recognise the very real hardship that many Australians are experiencing during the Prime Minister's `golden age'.

At about the time the Prime Minister was assuring Australians that `this is as good as it gets', over 70 per cent of the people in my electorate who returned a questionnaire I had sent to their homes said they were less financially secure than they had been three years ago. The community organisations providing emergency relief in my electorate have confirmed the implications of my survey.

During discussions with me, Anglican Community Services pointed out that the demand for welfare in both the northern and southern suburbs of metropolitan Adelaide continues to increase. This is in spite of what the Prime Minister has described as `the best conjunction of economic fundamentals in 30 years'. Perhaps the clearest indication of the government's failure to grasp the dimensions and nature of poverty and income inequality in Australia is its decision to cut funding to non-government providers of welfare.

In the last budget the Keating government cut emergency relief funding by $5 million to $14 million. A letter I have recently received from Lutheran Community Care based at Blair Athol in my electorate is indicative of the impact this funding cut will have on the provision of health to those in need. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to draw your attention to difficulties which our organisation is facing.
We have been assisting people with emergency relief (food vouchers etc) since our inception.
As the agency has developed, we have also expanded our services to our clients so that we can meet more than the surface needs.
We have available trained counsellors to address personal and relationship issues as well as trained financial counsellors who can address financial problems in a more preventative way.
Our aim is to empower our service users so that they are able to make some choices about their life situations.

Statistics provided in this letter show that Lutheran Community Care saw 1,098 clients in 1993-94 and 1,037 clients in 1994-95. The crucial point to be recognised is that there was no decrease in demand for the services provided by this agency over the past two financial years. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth government has seen fit to cut funding to this agency by a massive 24 per cent. The rationale for this funding cut is that the unemployment rate has fallen. Such a rationale betrays a frightening lack of understanding about the entrenchment of poverty in Australia. Poverty is no longer confined to the unemployed, and this is the reason the demand for services provided by Lutheran Community Care has not decreased in line with falls in the level of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: As has been pointed out in discussions with Lutheran Community Care, only one-third of those assisted are unemployed. The government's decision to reduce its funding of emergency relief services will result in fewer services. I quote further from the letter I received from Lutheran Community Care:

SPEECH.PARA: We are currently looking at our planning for the future and having to make decisions about what services we can and should provide.
Unless we can be assured of ongoing funding for this work, we will be forced to withdraw our services . . .

While the causes of poverty are complex, the failure of the Keating government to sustain economic recovery has been a major contributing factor. As I have said on previous occasions in this place, the very essence of the recoveries the Prime Minister oversees is their shallowness. They are fleeting recoveries in which fewer and fewer Australians get back on their feet before the bust. They are recoveries in which the economic sun shines briefly and each time it does it does so for an increasingly select few.

PARA.TAB: The relentless cycle of boom and bust that Australia has experienced over the last 13 years is dividing us into a society of haves and have nots. This trend can be reversed only by deep, sustained recovery which allows those most weakened by recession to participate in the rewards of growth.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the causes of increasing income inequity are complex and, as the Keating years have proven, economic growth, of itself, is not enough. It would be a foolish government that failed to heed the following words of Professor Bob Gregory:
As inequity in the world economy is greater than in Australia, the pressure on the Australian income distribution rises as the world becomes more integrated.
Increasingly, top Australian executives are comparing themselves to their counterparts offshore. At the same time however these same pressures are not so favourable for those at the bottom level.

There is a debilitating bleakness to life lived at the economic margins of our community. To abandon people to this wilderness diminishes the rest of us. There is an urgent need for those blinded by the brightness of their `golden age' to—in the immortal words of a former Western Australian Premier—`get real'. As a prelude to action, there must be an honest admission by the Keating government of its failure to address the issue of poverty and the growing gap between rich and poor in our country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before us gives this House an opportunity to discuss an important issue. Whilst I am not so naive as to not expect that the discussion that has preceded me would have as its basis political partisan views on the present situation, I hope that we can continue this discussion in a manner that will have a lasting benefit apart from political point scoring.

PARA.TAB: One of the difficulties that we confront when discussing poverty is that we have to try to come to grips with the ways in which it can be diagnosed. The report that was produced by the Queensland Council of Social Service, Drawing the line on poverty, used as its basis the Henderson poverty line. The Henderson poverty line has been a valuable tool to try to measure the extent of poverty throughout Australia for quite some time. But even at the time that Professor Henderson first put this measure in place, it was only a view of the extent of poverty. But it is important because it gives us, in a temporal sense, the longest series of figures to compare.

I had hoped that throughout the previous years of Labor governments we would come to grips with looking at measures that perhaps more readily reflected the extent of poverty throughout the community, but that has not been the case. So I, in a gentle way, criticise that perhaps we have not made that a priority. Of course, that is not the central issue that the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) goes to in moving this motion.

Even if we do not use the Henderson poverty line as a measure, if we use anecdotal evidence such as has been discussed this morning—the use of emergency relief—we can readily acknowledge that there are those who use charitable institutions to get meals and to have emergency accommodation and that that is a reflection that poverty is a problem in our society.

I readily acknowledge that from time to time comments that I make can be interpreted that I am anxious for the government to do more. But, fairly, I acknowledge that over the periods of Labor government in the federal sphere a raft of measures have been put in place which have directly attacked the alleviation of poverty, have tried to address the disparity between the rich and poor and have tried to address the disparity between the disadvantaged and the advantaged.

To use only income levels as the measure for assessing our achievements in those goals is to not recognise that there are other important things that impinge on people's quality of life and on people's ability to tackle their hopes and aspirations. We should not leave today's discussion without acknowledging that it is not only economic measures that are important to the way in which individuals and families are able to operate within the community. We have to acknowledge that economic policy, policy surrounding matters of social justice and even policy surrounding matters of the environment must be taken together in looking at people's so-called quality of life.

Many studies carried out over recent times have tried to better equip us to look at the issues that come under the banner of this motion. The honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) mentioned some of the studies by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling, whose director is Professor Anne Harding. Professor Harding has, over many years, championed the thought that we should be looking at those matters that fall under the nomenclature of the social wage and adding those to any studies that are simply based on income levels. Her studies have shown that, if we take into account those measures that can be called social wage measures, the disparity between the rich and the poor has narrowed and that those social wage measures to a large extent are able to lift the disadvantaged above what might be defined as the poverty level.

The various social wage measures include such things as social security benefits and child-care, health and education assistance for the disadvantaged. The honourable member for Hinkler's motion calls upon all Australian governments—I take that to mean not only the federal government but all the state governments and, indeed, local government authorities who can impact upon family and individual incomes through social wage measures—to address this issue.

The Queensland Council of Social Service report went to a number of measures that it thought were required to build an agenda for action on poverty. The report went to such diverse measures as concessions for public transport, which of course is in the hands of state government; public housing—which I acknowledge the council emphasised—and local area planning schemes. Local government authorities are called upon to play a role in ensuring that the newer developing suburbs and communities take into account the needs of affordable housing. In my area, through funding under the building better cities program, we are using former institutional land at Janefield to try to develop an urban planning scheme that will acknowledge the needs of the different life-cycle points of the community and the need for affordable housing.

Another telling part of the agenda that QCOSS called for was improvement to the education system. We have to acknowledge that these matters are important. In the state of Victoria, unfortunately, the downside of the measures that the Kennett government has undertaken under the banner of increasing economic efficiency is that they take away elements of the social wage.

In Queensland, QCOSS was asking for such things as specialist support staff and outreach programs to link schools and communities. They are the very programs which in Victoria are being diminished. QCOSS called for pre-service and in-service training courses to be developed to better equip teachers. In Victoria, these are the things that are being removed.

I do not introduce that simply to have a go at the Victorian government. My concern is the different philosophies. On the one hand, we have the Victorian government hell-bent on economic rationalism to create economic efficiencies without looking at the social cost of the things they are doing. If we look at international examples, whenever governments put in place economic rather than interventionist policies, that has been the result. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I support the motion of the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville). We must recognise that the report provided by QCOSS is not an up-to-date report. It is a report from an earlier time when both the Goss Labor government and the federal Labor government were firmly entrenched. The reflection must be on them.

PARA.TAB: It grieves me to hear the member for Capricornia (Mrs Henzell) trot out the statistic that two million jobs have been created in a certain period of time. I ask the government: what is the nature of a statistic like that when somebody has been put off, when they are homeless, when they are desperate, when they lack education facilities, when they lack the jobs that those two million have? There should be a lot more honesty from the government, if it is going to present those sorts of statistics, about what those two million jobs are. As we know, that figure relates mainly to casual workers with as little as two hours work per week.

There is a feeling of concern among welfare agencies in Queensland—and possibly among those in the rest of the country, although I speak only for my state. Don Cook from the Bundaberg Salvation Army, after waiting six weeks for his half-yearly federal emergency grant, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We've been treading water because we can't budget for anything and we've had to dip into our own limited funds, but the cupboard is bare.
Ned Makim, new editor of the Bundaberg News Mail, said in his editorial:
The news that Bundaberg welfare agencies have been reduced to begging for extra money to help families in need is infuriating.

PARA.TAB: We have accepted economic downturns, we have accepted high unemployment and we have had to deal with the drought.
Must we now have to accept that bureaucrats with their funding formulas have the right to ignore the genuine and real need of some in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: That says it all. The people from Centacare in my electorate have been desperate for funds to provide the welfare necessary in rural communities, mining towns and even in my own city. They have got down on their knees and begged me to do something. After two years of begging they are still being ignored, but they are the agencies that can put their services into action.

PARA.TAB: We have the ridiculous and ludicrous situation of governments funding new groups when old groups are already in the field. They already have the infrastructure and the knowledge. If extra funding had gone to them they could have provided services at the level required. Instead, through funding new agencies requiring new infrastructure, staff and everything else, the money has been dissipated.
But it is the second part of the motion that I think is important. It calls on all Australian governments to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . address the issue of poverty and the growing gap between rich and poor in this country.

I want to talk about the country. There is a lack of appreciation here about the country. I read in the paper and hear that for 30 days Sydney has not had rain. Areas of my electorate have been three years without a drop of rain—three years in which people have not been able to pasture their cattle. People have had to destock, and face huge interest rates. Yet the Queensland government's attitude is that, in spite of all this, there should be a user-pays basis for the value of the lease, increasing the cost of the lease—and there are also instructions that other conditions of the lease have to be fulfilled even though the country is in this condition.

PARA.TAB: Three years without rain, five years in a drought situation! The gap between the country and the city is growing day by day. There has to be a greater appreciation of what is happening.

It is not just a lack of wealth that is creating this new poor, who are not only primary producers but also local government workers, businesses, services—the people who make up a town. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)expresses its grave concern at the recommendations of the Industry Commission's draft report on the wine grape and wine industry in Australia and resists the increase in sales tax on wine and the imposition of an excise tax; and
(2)recognises the adverse effects that such tax structure changes would have on the export potential of the industry and on the expansion of wine grape plantings in the irrigated areas of Australia.

Almost all members of parliament would be familiar with the draft report into the Australian wine industry. Almost all of them would have seen this report and most will be familiar with its contents, much of which is the result of a report by the committee of inquiry into the wine grape and wine industry that followed the 1993 budget statement of this government. It recommended, effectively, an increase in the tax proportion and tax burden being carried by the Australian wine industry.

PARA.TAB: What many members are unaware of, however, is that the final report is currently on the desk of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins). The Australian wine industry is waiting for Minister Collins to make a decision on the recommendations of the final report. Those recommendations are unknown to the industry and are unknown to all members of this House, apart, of course, from Minister Collins. The particular concern that I have and the particular concern that the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) has is that the recommendations of the draft report should not be implemented; nor, we hope, are they part of the recommendations currently being considered by Senator Collins in the currently private final report.

We have a situation where an industry which has become the benchmark for export development in Australia is currently under threat as a result of the recommendations of an inquiry that would suit a government anxious to collect additional tax. This is an industry that has a targeted export performance. This is an industry that intends to export over $1 billion worth of product—Australian product, value added product—in the year 2001. We, as members of a parliament that ought to be worried about the nation's balance of payments, should be committing ourselves to do all we can to encourage the export performance of this benchmark Australian industry.

The wine industry in Australia is on target. If you travel around my electorate and the electorates of the members for Riverina, Barker (Mr McLachlan) and Mallee (Mr Forrest), you will see a veritable forest of pine posts appearing as people trellis new young vines in anticipation of reaching the industry's export target of $1 billion.

As a South Australian, I have a particular interest in this industry because last year seven per cent of South Australia's export dollars came from this industry and the contribution this industry will make to South Australia's economic recovery will come as its performance in the export market continues to increase. It is expected that this industry will see an increase in plantings across Australia of 8,000 hectares over the next few years. Effectively, 40 per cent of that planting may well occur in South Australia.
Mr Cleeland interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It cannot occur in both, with reference to the member for McEwen. This is an industry on target to perform and an industry currently under threat of being taxed out of existence. The reason that the opposition, particularly the member for Riverina and I, are concerned about this is that we do not want to see this industry treated as its sister industry, the brandy industry, was in the past.

PARA.TAB: There will be some who will say, `If the industry is performing this well, shouldn't it carry an additional tax burden?' Let me indicate to you just how cost sensitive this industry is and just how desperate its participants are to perform in a national sense. Historically, grapes would always have been planted in rectangular blocks, irrigated either by a drip irrigation system where water was scarce or by a flood irrigation system where in the past water was more plentiful. In 1995, that sort of extension is largely becoming historic.

I spoke only a month ago to the principal vineyard manager for Orlando Wines, one of Australia's largest producers, and he indicated that the current expansion they are involved in is computer irrigation. More than that, all of their plantings currently occurring in South Australia occur only after a soil profile has been done. They determine which are the heavier soils and which are the lighter soils. Where the heavier soils exist a dripper with a different rate of water application will be applied relative to those vines of a different variety being planted in a lighter soil.

The entire area has computerised irrigation, ensuring that each vine has delivered to it only the water it needs. As if that were not enough, premium varieties are being planted in the soils that most suit them and they are planted on trellises that allow them to be mechanically harvested and mechanically pruned so that Australia's wine industry can continue to take on the rest of the world.

In spite of this expansion, the Australian wine industry only makes up 2.2 per cent of the world trade in exported wine. If we want to continue to increase that proportion, we have to be efficient, which is just what they are endeavouring to be, and we have to maintain our reputation for quality and our image that the nation has for being a producer of clean and green product.

The government needs to be aware of those things that are unique about the Australian wine industry. One of the things that separates the wine industry from other industries is that it has a long lead time and a large investment per hectare. All members in the House will be familiar with the fact that anyone who is committing themselves to the future of the Australian wine industry is committing themselves to an industry in which they will have invested a great deal of money before they get any real return.

This is an industry which only 10 years ago faced a vine pull because its export future and its market future was unknown. It has effectively pulled itself up by its own bootstraps. It is also an industry which only 12 years ago carried no sales tax at all.

No-one will remember more clearly than the member for Riverina the commitment of former Prime Minister Hawke, who in the member for Riverina's electorate said, `Not only does this industry have no sales tax, but under this government it will not have a sales tax.' What has happened? The sales tax on the wine industry, which was at zero and was maintained at zero thanks to the effective work of the Fraser government and of my predecessor, the late Geoffrey O'Halloran Giles, under this government went to 10 per cent despite that promise. As if that was not enough, it then went to 20 per cent. And, as if that was not enough, under the 1993 budget statement it was proposed that it go to 32 per cent. That is where it would be if it were not for this committee of inquiry.

The committee of inquiry's draft report has itself recommended a further tax increase and, worse than that, a volumetric tax. We are opposed not to the wine industry being taxed—the coalition has had a consistent voting pattern: we supported the initial tax, recognising that you cannot have an alcoholic beverage without expecting it to carry some tax, and resisted subsequent tax rises, which were nothing more than a hungry grab from a desperate government—but to a volumetric tax, because that is the tax that most unfairly impinges on the large proportion of the wine industry located in electorates such as mine in the Riverland area, such as that of the member for Mallee in the Sunraysia area and such as that of the member for Riverina in the Murrumbidgee irrigation area. Frankly, a volumetric tax ruins this industry because it undercuts the domestic market on which the export industry is based and flows on and adversely affects the dried fruit industry as well.

This must not be viewed superficially by the government or treated by the government as it is treated by the Australian Democrats; that is, an excuse to spend more money in alcohol education. The wine industry has a proud record of building its own alcohol education base. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—At the outset I say to the House that this motion has my full and unqualified support. In saying that, I remind the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) that he was very quiet when his party proposed a 15 per cent fringe benefits tax on wine. It is not becoming to come into this place and solely attack the government on taxes on wine when the fringe benefits tax of 15 per cent would have had a profound impact on the Australian wine industry. Having said that, I say that the member for Wakefield has been a consistent supporter of the industry and I join him today in fully supporting this motion.

PARA.TAB: People in this House know that the electorate of McEwen, as it now is and as it will be in the next election, represents the major area of wine production in Victoria, running through from the vineyards around the granite country of Heathcote, around through the Goulburn Valley and now down into the Yarra Valley. Victoria is indeed the home of great wine production, particularly table wine. There are substantial increased plantings occurring right throughout Victoria. Indeed, Tyrrells Vineyards from New South Wales has recently bought land around the Heathcote area, which the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) would be quite familiar with. Tyrrells are establishing a major new vineyard area around Heathcote. The industry in Victoria is one of great growth and of great economic importance to the area.

I have a view that a country's industry policy should firstly reflect the strengths of that country's production. Australia's industry policy should firstly look at and examine the strengths of production in this country. Agriculture across the board is one of the great strengths of Australian production. We provide clean, pollution-free food. It can be value added and it can be exported.

More recently, one of the great tragedies in industry growth has been the lack of interest in the Australian investment market of the food processing companies previously owned by Pacific Dunlop. This country wants to have a really good think about itself when its major institutional investors have failed to support Philip Brass and Pacific Dunlop in their rather bold venture to bring value adding of food under the one roof. The fact that the Australian institutional investors did not support Pacific Dunlop meant that those companies were sold overseas.

Frankly, I find that to be alarming, and I am very critical of Australian institutional investors for allowing it to happen. It is a great pity that the vision of Philip Brass and Pacific Dunlop was not borne out by market conditions here. The fact that those assets were sold for some $1.8 billion over and above that at which the market had valued them in Australia indicates that Philip Brass was right in his assessment of those industries and their worth.

The wine industry is part of value adding to agriculture. It is a major growth industry. It is an industry which has enormous potential in export income. It takes the raw commodity, the grape, to a juice, to the bottling of a highly sophisticated product that we call wine. However, it is but one of the many fine food products that Australian agriculture can make. I have been and will continue to be a critic of the present method of taxation of wine in this country.

The first thing I am critical of is the fact that wine is treated as manufactured trading stock. That is, our taxation regime requires that wine, in its year of manufacture, be brought to account as income in the year of production. For an industry which can value add by ageing wine, it has never made sense to me that we say to a wine producer, `You have to pay tax on the imputed value of your wine production in the year of production.' It has never made sense to me that a country which is looking for exports and which has such magnificent value added potential with wine prohibits the ageing of wine with the use of the taxation regime by calling wine trading stock.

Wine is not manufactured in the sense of pencils, pens or other materials; it is an agricultural product which will be of great value if it can be left to age. Because of that tax regime I have mentioned, Australian wine manufacturers have developed techniques which allow them to bring wine into production and sale much more quickly than with earlier methods where it was traditional to lay it down in a cellar to get that magnificent ageing process.

Unfortunately, Australian wine manufacturers do not now put their good wines through a major ageing process because it is simply not cost effective and they are taxed out of the ability to do so, yet that is an area which I think any industry policy should examine and do things about. That would make the industry more attractive and more profitable and allow the industry to produce ageing wines which have a greater market value overseas. That is one area I have always been critical of, and I still hope one day to see some change in that.

We are talking about an industry with a potential export growth increase of some $1.3 billion. We are talking about an industry where we can achieve approximately a five per cent share of the world's wine market by the year 2010. We are talking about an industry which is now seen throughout the world as a manufacturer of a very fine product. You can now travel to countries such as England and Europe and find Australian wines competing against the very best wines produced anywhere in the world—and it competes at a price. So it is a very competitive industry in a very competitive marketplace. It is essential that that competitive nature of the industry be maintained.

As a politician, I have been a student of the wine industry for a number of years. I am familiar with a number of reports which have been brought down—a Victorian parliamentary report and a federal parliamentary report, which both touched on the lack of elasticity in the price of wine in the marketplace. In fact, it is quite clear that, economically, wine has a very low elasticity in price. In other words, if you increase the price of wine at the retail level, your sales will drop off. That lack of elasticity in the price of wine has been referred to in many reports and on many occasions. Of course, any tax adds to the price of the wine at the retail level. Obviously, with wine being so competitive, the margins are very fine and producers cannot afford to carry any increased taxes and have to pass them on to the consumer. That lack of elasticity immediately impacts on the sales of wines—and their sales drop.

If we are going to be successful in overseas markets, then we have to encourage domestic production. The producer who is going to put some $10,000 per hectare in the planting of young vines has to carry those vines for up to five years before he is going to get any production growth out of it and any income return back. If our producers are going to become exporters, first of all, we have to ensure and encourage their domestic production and have a very healthy domestic market for them.

Many people I know in the industry have started off as domestic producers and have now gone into exports. For example, the Delatite vineyard near Mansfield is one of the real cold climate producers in Australia whose rieslings and chardonnays are now widely sought after in London. It now has a major English exporting business out of the Delatite area at the base of Mount Buller. That is an unusual place to grow wine—believe me, in winter it is very cold—yet it produces some brilliant cold climate wines. There is a whole host of vineyards in my electorate that are similar. Mount St Helens, for example, in the Strathbogie Ranges is now a very large producer of cold climate chardonnay. Mount St Helens is a brand which is produced in Echuca, but the grapes are actually grown in the Strathbogie Ranges in Victoria.

We have to encourage these people. Any increase in taxes is not the sort of encouragement we should be giving them. It is no secret I have opposed any increase in ad valorem taxes. I think the current tax of 26 per cent ad valorem is more than enough for the industry to carry. I was quite shocked and horrified when I read the report of the Industry Commission on the industry. A tax based on volume, quite frankly, is an absolute nonsense. I am sometimes astonished when people say they understand industry and are in a position of publicly involving themselves in industry direction and then come up with such quaint and nonsense arguments. Anyone who knows anything about the industry would know that it cannot carry a volume tax on wine. It really cannot carry any increase on wine.

I declare my full support for the motion and congratulate the member for Wakefield for raising it. I will certainly be maintaining my position within the government and putting my views consistently to the government, as I have in the past. I am sure other members on this side of the House representing vineyards and the wine industry will not be far behind me.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of eagerness that I support the motion by the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). As the member for Wakefield said, it takes me back to 1983 when I was standing outside the Yoogali Club, in the seat of Riverina in the town of Griffith, and inside the former Prime Minister was saying, `Labor has pledged not to impose a sales tax or an excise tax on wine. The taxation disadvantages suffered by the wine makers with respect to stockholding will be objectively examined on the basis that wine making is a primary production process, not a manufacturing industry.' The reason the then Prime Minister was making this promise was that he knew how important the wine making industry was to the Riverina and to the wine making areas of Australia.

PARA.TAB: We know that these promises have been broken. Since then the wine making industry has faced a very hostile tax regime—the latest being the decision taken in the August 1993 budget to increase the sales tax on wine from 20 to 31 per cent. Industry outcry persuaded the government to revise the tax to 22 per cent for 1993-94.

TALK.START.PARA: —So did the opposition.

—So did the opposition—including the member for Wakefield, who played a major role. Industry held the government to a 22 per cent tax for the 1993-94 season. The government then progressively raised it to 26 per cent by July 1996, and the matter was referred to the Industry Commission. The commission has now met, and that is what this motion is about today.

PARA.TAB: The major problem with the wine industry is the uncertainty it faces. The government, as in many instances where it is involved, seems to keep changing the rules of the game. This government is a big spending government with a voracious appetite for tax. It has to get tax wherever it can.

Despite the tax regimes and the impositions, the industry has managed to get on with the job and show what can be done by an industry that is keen, has the technology and is prepared to work. This commission has released a draft report, which shows that conflicting views are held among the three panel members of the committee of inquiry on the matter of an appropriate taxation regime for the wine industry. The worst cases were put by the chairman, Mr Scales, whose recommendations are that there be a 32 per cent wholesale sales tax and an additional tax, in common with the rest of the panel members—a specific tax of $4 per litre of alcohol. The combined effect of these two taxes, as proposed by Mr Scales, is equivalent to doubling the current sales tax on wine. We know that neither of these recommendations is acceptable.

I cannot understand why a government which needs taxes, because it is a big spender, has a huge foreign debt and is supposedly keen to assist industry in creating jobs, would carry out these recommendations. The sooner the government comes out and says, `We're not going to take any notice of these recommendations, but we'll accept the recommendations of the wine industry,' the better off the industry and the government will be.

I would like to raise the issue of the effect that it will have on the wine electorates. My electorate is presently exporting the technology of the wine making industry in Australia to places such as France. The Ron Potter rotary fermenter is a good case in point. We are building wineries in France, California, Chile, Cyprus, China and Vietnam using Australian state-of-the-art technology. This is employing people in the manufacturing industry.

In the meantime, research and development is going on in Australia. At Charles Sturt University at Wagga Wagga, for example, there are more people this year doing a tertiary education course in wine making than there has ever been before. Most importantly, by the year 2000 we will be employing another 7,000 people in vineyards throughout Australia and another 7,000 in the wineries. If that is not enough for the government, I do not know what the wine industry has to do.

We should be taking note of the wine industry. Let us have a look at exports. I will quickly list some wineries in the Riverina area. McWilliams is exporting 30,000 to 60,000 cases of wine to Japan during the first year of its 10-year contract. Miranda, De Bortoli and Cranswick wineries are exporting and making additional revenue for Australia as are other wineries in the Riverina.

I call on the government to reject this finding, to adopt the recommendations of the industry to not put a tax on wine and to have a look at the present holding tax regime imposed on the wine industry. In this way you will protect the jobs of many people in rural areas and help our export industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —In summary, the motion before us today calls on the House to express its concern over the recommendations of the Industry Commission's draft report on the wine grape and wine industry in Australia and to resist the increase in sales tax on wine and the imposition of an excise tax. It also calls on the House to recognise the adverse effects that such tax structure changes would have on the export potential of the industry.

PARA.TAB: I associate myself with those concerns. My interest in the wine industry is as a result of part of the Swan Valley in Western Australia being in my electorate. The regional centre of Midland forms the southern part of the Swan Valley. The Swan Valley is a great quality wine producing area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I see that the parliamentary secretary at the table has obviously ventured through the Swan Valley from time to time. In South Guildford in my electorate there is the Olive Farm winery, which is the oldest commercial producing winery in Western Australia. In the area of Caversham is the Sandalfords winery. PARA.TAB: The strength of the Swan Valley wine industry is that, in the main, these are small wineries which have been handed down through hard work from generation to generation. SPEECH.PARA: 5.22Sales tax is levied on products used for promotional purposes, including samples that are given away. This affects wine makers who use some of their product for tasting purposes and is particularly onerous for operators of small wineries who rely on cellar door sales. For these operators, sales tax constitutes double taxation as the cost of samples, including their tax component, is built into the price of goods that are sold.
The committee went on to say:

5.23The Committee notes two dimensions to this issue. A special exemption for cellar door wineries could be administratively complicated because of differences in the way cellar door tastings are conducted, for example, some wineries charge a tasting fee and others include tastings as part of a food and beverage package.(78) In addition, an exemption would be inequitable unless it applied to all samples given away for promotional purposes. These wineries are all relatively small, but they are all growing. They are part of one of the true growth primary industries in Australia at the moment. They are expanding. One only needs to travel overseas and go into areas as remote as Banff in Canada and walk into one of the licensed bottle outlets to find not a few bottles of Australian wines but a whole section devoted to Australian wines because the quality is good, and there is a whole range of products from right throughout Australia—from the electorate of the member for Wakefield, from the electorate of the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) and also from the electorate that I represent at the moment. Australian companies are really getting a solid toehold in the wine market overseas. Why on earth would a government want to destroy that by adding additional tax to it? I cannot for the life of me understand why any government would try to destroy a primary industry that is now establishing itself in world export markets and growing at a rapid rate and where there is still future potential for growth. A paper which was forwarded to me recently said:

SPEECH.PARA: To supply the 2010 growth opportunities the Australian wine industry would have to:
.increase wine production by 420m litres.

That is just an indication of the type of growth that is available to wine producers in this country. To add a volumetric tax to an industry where wine is vulnerable to the vagaries of nature and is typified by long lead times in production and investment payback astounds me and the people in the industry.

PARA.TAB: We have just come through one of the most difficult periods—one of the worst droughts—in north central Victorian agricultural history. That is another factor in wine production. The volume is down but the quality is up, and it is one of the other factors that wine producers have to contend with.

I say to the government: reject this report for the increased volumetric tax that is being proposed in this inquiry and report. I would have liked to have heard the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) come out more strongly in support of this motion that has been put up by the member for Wakefield. I fear that some of the other members on the other side of the House are not really sincere about their support for the motion proposed by the member for Wakefield. They should be making their voices heard loudly and clearly outside to the wine industry people to enable them to plan for the future. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Somewhat surprisingly, I find myself supporting the motion moved by the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). I do so gladly. It reflects no credit on the previous speaker, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), to suggest that we on this side of the House who oppose any increased taxation for wine are not sincere.

PARA.TAB: There is a television advertisement which says, `If you drink and drive, you're a bloody idiot.' If the Industry Commission's final report of its inquiry into the wine industry recommends that the wine industry be hit with increased taxation, the Industry Commission is a bloody idiot. If this government implements recommendations to increase taxation on the wine industry, this government too has lost its sanity.

In the brief moments available to me, I make the following points. Few people in this parliament know the wine industry as well as the members who have taken part in this debate. All speakers—Labor, Liberal and National Party—have opposed increased taxation on the wine industry. Parliamentarians who know the wine industry know the problems of that industry. There is a reluctance to invest in a new industry undertaking, knowing that that undertaking will provide nil return until the passage of between six and eight years.

Surely I do not have to outline the losses sustained by the industry as a result of crippling drought. To contemplate an increased tax on wine at this time is absolute madness. The honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) is quite correct in referring to the unfair tax practice of taxing wine while it is being withheld for maturation.

How many members know that wine donated to charity is taxed, and that wine used for tasting purposes is taxed? I would estimate that thousands of litres of wine per year are donated by Hunter vignerons to various charities throughout the Hunter Valley. All those bus loads of people who visit the Hunter on tourist excursions sip their wine and not all of them buy. The vignerons give away so much wine for which they receive absolutely no return.

An increased tax on wine is really a punishment imposed on entrepreneurial success. Our wine industry has tremendous potential if crazy taxes do not kill off investment. Increased wine taxes certainly will kill off investment in an industry which, as other speakers have said, has the potential to earn huge export dollars and assist our trading problems. Kill the wine industry and what happens? First of all, we kill off employment. Areas like the Hunter, which for too long have been dependent on one industry—coal—have undergone a resurgence in living standards and opportunities because of the development of the wine industry and the development of the tourist industry.

We can be sure of one thing: increased taxation on wine will destroy the tourist potential of the Hunter, will kill off wine production, will throw hundreds of people out of work and will devastate country areas like the Hunter and other parts of Australia. The people engaged in that industry are not glitzy socialites from major capital cities; they are men and women—Labor voters—who have managed to find employment in the wine industry. As I said, any attempt to impose increased taxation on the wine industry would be quite catastrophic.
