SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haviland Mr C.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes the unanimous resolution of the NSW Parliament of 9 December 1991 calling upon the federal Government to establish a top level, open, joint NSW/federal Government inquiry into the bombing of the Sydney Hilton Hotel on 13 February 1978 and pledging the full cooperation of the NSW Government;
(2)notes the recent statements of the NSW Premier, Mr Bob Carr, confirming his Government's support for such an inquiry;

(3)requests that the federal Government immediately establish a joint federal/NSW Government inquiry, with the powers of a Royal Commission, into all of the circumstances and consequences surrounding the Hilton Hotel bombing, including the events leading up to the incident, the bombing itself, the conduct of the subsequent investigation of the bombing and all relevant matters;

(4)requests that the terms of reference for the inquiry include a full investigation of the role played by all NSW and federal Government agencies, including military and security organisations, before, during and after the bombing; and

(5)requests that any provisions existing in any federal legislation which would otherwise prevent full disclosure to the inquiry by officers, employees, agents or sub-agents of federal Government agencies of any information under oath relevant to the terms of reference be set aside for the purposes of the inquiry.

On Monday, 13 February 1978 at 12.40 a.m., a bomb exploded outside the Hilton Hotel in George Street, Sydney. The bomb had been placed in a rubbish bin which was being emptied into a Sydney City Council garbage truck compactor. The Hilton Hotel was the venue for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting which was to commence later that day. Twelve heads of government were staying at the hotel, including the then Australian Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser.

PARA.TAB: Three people were killed by the explosion. They were Police Constable Paul Burmistriw and two council employees, William Favell and Alex Carter. Several other people received severe and permanent injuries as a result of the bombing. In some cases, such as that of Senior Constable Terry Griffiths, it destroyed their careers as well as their health.

In addition, three members of the Ananda Marga sect spent years in gaol for crimes they did not commit and were falsely implicated in the Hilton bombing. One of the three, Timothy Anderson, was later convicted for the Hilton bombing, was again wrongfully imprisoned but acquitted in 1991 by the New South Wales Court of Appeal. Despite the gravity of this incident, which appeared at that time to be the first serious case of terrorism in Australia, there has never been a satisfactory investigation into the full circumstances of the bombing. Indeed, it remains Australia's most serious unsolved murder case.

There are many unanswered questions about the events of 13 February 1978. But it is worth noting that the bombing came at a time when there was much public criticism of our security forces, including serious questioning of the need for their existence. The Dunstan government in South Australia had abolished the South Australian Police special branch following the White inquiry, and other states were considering following suit.

The ABC's documentary Conspiracy, screened on 19 February 1995, revealed that in the National Library files there are 10 times more press clippings relating to security matters for the month of January 1978 than for an average month's coverage in the last 30 years. The public criticism and questioning apparently caused concern amongst security forces and amongst some conservative governments who were said to be keen to maintain links between ASIO and special branches.

Following the Hilton bombing and the accompanying concern about international terrorism, ASIO received a 25 per cent increase in funding in the 1978 federal budget. That was when the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was Treasurer. It was his first budget—the same budget in which he took back the fistful of dollars promised at the 1977 election. ASIO was also granted substantially increased powers in the ASIO Act, passed in 1979.

In June 1978 three members of the Ananda Marga sect—Timothy Anderson, Paul Alister and Ross Dunn—were arrested and charged with attempting to murder a right-wing extremist, Robert Cameron, with a bomb, which was alleged to be similar to the bomb used in the Hilton bombing. With the help of evidence from Richard Seary, who had infiltrated the Margas at the request of the New South Wales Police special branch, the three men were convicted and spent seven years in gaol.

In 1982, 4 1/2 years after the Hilton bombing, a coronial inquest commenced. This inquest turned out to be a farce and proved totally inadequate. Far from solving the crime, it failed to examine important evidence. Key witnesses were prevented from appearing, and crucial evidence was therefore suppressed. However, Richard Seary was again allowed to give evidence, which claimed that Dunn, Alister and Anderson had been responsible for the Hilton bombing. This led to a prima facie case being found against them, and the inquest was therefore terminated, amid uproar in the courtroom. However, no charges were laid.

In 1985, the Wood inquiry found that a doubt remained as to the three men's guilt over the attempted murder of Cameron. They were released from prison and received a pardon. In 1980, the then Attorney-General of New South Wales, Frank Walker—now the honourable member for Robertson and the federal Minister for Administrative Services—had interviewed a Commonwealth scientist who claimed that he had been requested by ASIO to make two bombs, shortly before the Hilton bombing in February 1978.

The scientist, whose identity has never been made public, had been referred to Mr Walker by the then federal shadow Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans. In 1981, Mr Peter Monaghan, an adviser to the then Australian Democrats Senator Colin Mason, told Mr Terry Griffiths, a victim of the bombing, that he had received a visit from two men claiming to be from ASIO. The men told Mr Monaghan that ASIO had been involved in the Hilton bombing.

There has been much said on the public record over many years regarding this affair. Time does not permit me to cover it all, but the fact remains that not only does the murder of three people remain unresolved but evidence continues to mount which has created real concern in the community. This concern is not just going to go away. This parliament cannot continue to ignore this issue. That is why I have moved this motion in the House today.

In December 1991, the New South Wales parliament unanimously passed a motion calling for a joint federal-New South Wales government inquiry and pledged the cooperation of the New South Wales government. I am now calling on this House to support my motion which is in similar terms. The new New South Wales Premier, Bob Carr, has confirmed his support for such an inquiry.

He does have the option of conducting a New South Wales inquiry, but this would clearly be of limited value as it is vital that all relevant federal agencies and subagencies participate fully and that witnesses under Commonwealth jurisdiction are able to be called to give evidence under oath and without any restrictions placed on them by secrecy provisions of any federal legislation, as outlined in part (5) of my motion. This is essential in order to get to the bottom of the matter, uncover the truth and force these agencies to be accountable for their activities.

I note that the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has stated that the Commonwealth would fully cooperate in any inquiry established by the New South Wales government provided sensitive material is protected. However, for the reasons I have outlined, I do not believe this goes far enough. We need a full, open, joint federal-New South Wales inquiry with the powers of a royal commission. As for the reference to sensitive material, I believe it is unacceptable for security forces to hide behind so-called secrecy and avoid accountability in matters as serious as this one.

The Attorney-General also said that the federal Labor government would have no reason to be embarrassed by any revelations regarding the involvement of Commonwealth agencies in the bombing because the government of the day was, of course, the Fraser Liberal government. I can only agree with that. Indeed, one of the matters which could be examined is the role of Mr Fraser and his office in the security arrangements, as well as the Fraser government's attitude towards the abolition of special branches in the states, and the role of ASIO and other security services in the light of the South Australian White inquiry. I am advised that Mr Fraser himself took over responsibility for security at the Hilton Hotel shortly before the bomb blast on 13 February 1978.

Having said that, I do not want to make this a partisan political issue. It is fair to point out that the resolution of the New South Wales parliament in 1991—under a state Liberal government—was unanimous, and that people such as Peter Collins, the then New South Wales Attorney-General and current opposition leader, have repeatedly, to their credit, supported the need for a joint inquiry. But there are many other questions the inquiry could investigate.

Time is short, but the questions include: why were the army sniffer dogs, which were specially trained and prepared for the CHOGRM conference at the Hilton, mysteriously called off four days before the bombing? Despite official denials, this has been confirmed by ex Corporal Keith Burley, who was in charge of the army sniffer dog squad at the time. I have a copy of his letter to former New South Wales MP John Hatton dated 4 November 1991.

Why was the rubbish bin outside the Hilton the only one in Sydney not emptied by council workers on the weekend before the bombing? Police had prevented council workers from emptying the bin on three occasions prior to the explosion. Why was no explosive residue found at the scene? Did ASIO request a Commonwealth scientist to make two bombs in 1978 in the weeks leading up to the bombing?

On the last point, there are also questions arising from the report of the now retired Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, Mr Roger Holdich, which was tabled in this House on 28 June 1995. The report states on page 51 that Senator Gareth Evans provided Mr Holdich with the name of the Commonwealth scientist who approached him in 1980. Mr Holdich states that he found no evidence of ASIO involvement in the making of bombs in 1978 but the report fails to state whether or not Mr Holdich interviewed the scientist in question. Did Mr Holdich interview the scientist? If so, what was the result; if not, why not?

It has also been alleged that Mr Holdich himself worked for a security organisation at the time of the bombing. I do not know if that is true, but if it were true a cynical observer might question the credibility of his report, which clears ASIO of any improper conduct or any involvement in the Hilton bombing.

All of this demonstrates that there is an urgent need in the public interest for a top level inquiry to bring out the facts. Who was responsible for the Hilton bombing? Has there been a cover-up? If it is good enough for the New South Wales parliament, this parliament should follow suit. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting this motion I would like to quote Shakespeare's dictum: `Foul deeds will rise, though all the earth o'erwhelm them to men's eyes.' If that does not move this House, the example of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) should be enough to show what happens to those who stand in the way of truth.

PARA.TAB: The Hilton bombing was Australia's greatest act of terrorism and it marred what up till then had been Australia's greatest international gathering. As a result, a man was charged and convicted but all the time protesting that he was the victim of a frame-up. Eventually, after several years in gaol, he was completely exonerated.

Years later, another man confessed and, on the basis of that confession, was charged and convicted. But any confidence in our knowing what really happened depends entirely on the slender thread of the confession of an unstable and delusional man.

There are those who would say that the law has spoken, therefore there is nothing left to be investigated, but it is not as simple as that. First of all, we have the evidence of Corporal Keith Burley, who was in charge of the army sniffer dog squad. In a letter some years ago he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Approximately two weeks prior to the Hilton bombing the operational team was placed on standby for the CHOGM Conference. We were told specifically to train the dogs on such things as letter bombs and parcel bombs. This we did by making up these articles using live explosives. We trained specifically for this task for almost two weeks. On the Thursday before the Hilton bombing we received information at the kennels saying that we were no longer required. This we thought was very unusual to say the least. We attempted to find out why but were unable to determine where the `cancellation' came from. All I know is that it came through Victoria Barracks in Sydney.
He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: There was a lot of rumour and innuendo going around at the time we were at the scene. The strongest being that ASIO had stuffed up. It was common comment around at the time that ASIO had in fact planted the device and planned to find it for whatever purpose, but the garbage men were early that morning.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we had the statements of Frank Walker, now Minister for Administrative Services, who was visited by a scientist who claimed to have been involved in making bombs for ASIO. The Sydney Morning Herald states:

PARA.TAB: "He was a fairly impressive guy," Walker, now a Federal Labor MP, said this week. "He was disaffected with the CSIRO but he seemed to be a responsible person."

The scientist said that CSIRO, on at least several occasions, had made bombs for ASIO. In the weeks leading up to February 13, 1978—when a bomb killed two garbage collectors and a policeman outside the Sydney Hilton, venue for a meeting of Commonwealth leaders—there had been an "order" for at least two bombs. ASIO wanted them in a hurry: Walker recalls the scientist saying that the organisation came under a great deal of pressure to produce them.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened was that Frank Walker, then a minister in the New South Wales government, ordered an investigation by New South Wales government officials. He affirms positively and indubitably that he saw a written report arising out of that investigation. Let me congratulate the Minister for Administrative Services. I wish he had shown the same passion for the truth in the Botany council case, but an incomplete passion for the truth is better than none at all.

PARA.TAB: The Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security now says that no investigation ever took place and no records or reports even exist. So either the Minister for Administrative Services is lying or the files have been tampered with. I do not believe that the Minister for Administrative Services is a liar, but that in effect is what was said in the Holdich report, the report which the current Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) is doing his best to defend.

The Attorney-General wrote last month to the Sydney Morning Herald, claiming that an earlier answer to a question on notice comprehensively disproved the sniffer dog theory. Let us look at the answer the Attorney-General referred to. The answer provided by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and given by the member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Officer Commanding the Military Dog Wing probably ordered his soldiers to undertake some training relating to—
the CHOGM conference.
It is unlikely that there was dedicated training for the possible task for a full two weeks.
The wing—
that is, the dog wing—

may have been given an order to stand down . . . The commanding Officer of the School cannot recall giving such a direction. However, he does not rule out the possibility. It is not known if any explanation was given.

Quite frankly, these are weasel words. The truth, which is quite clear even on the basis of the minister's old answer, is that the army sniffer dog squad was asked to prepare and they were told to stop. The only explanation given by the minister was that the police did not follow up their initial request for army help.

PARA.TAB: The dog squad was told to prepare for a terrorist attack. It was not confirmed in quadruplicate from the official sources so they assumed, we are asked to believe, that the terrorist attack was no longer a possibility. This just beggars belief. If the Attorney-General believes that this constitutes comprehensive disproof, he would believe anything. He would probably believe that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) tells the truth! In a letter to one of the victims of the Hilton bomb, the Attorney-General magnanimously said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that Commonwealth agencies would co-operate fully with any inquiry which the Government of New South Wales established, subject, of course, to agreement on suitable arrangements to protect any sensitive material to which such an inquiry might be given access. I confirm that position.

In other words, the Attorney-General is saying that you can inquire into anything you like except the truth, and you can have any information you need except information that might incriminate the Commonwealth government.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Attorney-General: what kind of Sir Humphrey Applebys are there in his department that he is prepared to operate on this basis? The Minister for Administrative Services is concerned. He believes there should be an inquiry. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and former Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, has placed on record his concerns about these matters. Bob Carr, the Premier of New South Wales, has said that he is concerned about these matters, and the whole of the New South Wales parliament has passed a resolution calling for a full and independent Commonwealth-state investigation into these matters. They all think there is something wrong. Why doesn't the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth?

Our job is not, here in this parliament, to specifically probe into the dark and murky labyrinth of the security forces. Our job is to ensure that people who can do that job are allowed to do that job. Our job is to help establish an inquiry which can get to the bottom of this matter. It is so important that we do this because the people of this country are entitled to believe and to be confident that the forces of government, the security forces of this country, are working for them and not against them. The people of this country are entitled to have confidence that the various arms of government are working in accordance with the law and not, as it very well may be in this case, against the law.

Let me say most categorically that truth has nothing to fear from an inquiry. The government should have nothing to fear from an inquiry. ASIO should have nothing to fear from an inquiry. The police should have nothing to fear, the army should have nothing to fear from an inquiry, because truth has nothing to fear from an inquiry. This government should not be so concerned about the cost of an inquiry because truth is priceless; truth is precious. Any government which is prepared to spend $17 million investigating war crimes that happened in another country 50 years ago should certainly be prepared to help fund an inquiry of this nature.

Let all the documents be considered. Let all the witnesses be examined. Let all the options be considered and canvassed. Let the best conclusion possible be drawn, because the fact is we do not need to have this issue hanging over our heads in the way the JFK murder is hanging over the heads of people in the United States. I say to the Attorney-General: don't do a Carmen Lawrence on us. Don't say to the parliament, `Of course I want the truth to come out, but I just don't seem to be able to find a suitable venue in which to tell it.' Don't do a Carmen Lawrence on us, Attorney-General, because you are better than that. The ghosts of three innocent men are hovering over us today. Let us get to the bottom of this so that their souls can finally rest in peace.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that this morning, with the motion of the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), we might have heard something new that this government has not already considered. I come with some background of having looked at this matter extremely carefully and I must say that the recent decision by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) not to support a royal commission is something which, on all the evidence available to me, I support unequivocally.

PARA.TAB: I think there are a few questions that should be answered this morning, and I want to go through them in a bit of detail. The first question is: why do people want an inquiry into the Hilton bombing? We heard one new one this morning, and that was from the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) who said that it was common knowledge that ASIO planted the bomb. That is his view. Other people want an inquiry because they think, similar to the view expressed by the honourable member for Warringah, that it was ASIO which conspired to plant the bomb, for reasons which were then dealt with earlier by the honourable member for Macarthur, because he pointed out, as other people have, that at the time the whole question of security agencies and the need for them was very much an issue in the public domain.

The second question is that this government is resisting an inquiry because it wants to cover up embarrassing facts. I want to clear up that allegation of embarrassment first, which was dealt with to some extent by the honourable member for Macarthur.

I ask the people in this House and those who have taken some interest in this matter—the member for North Sydney (Mr Mack) is listed to speak; he took some interest, not necessarily on his own behalf, but as a result of views put by other people to him—to just consider a few things. What conceivable reason would this government have? Why would I, as Attorney-General, the present Attorney-General or anybody else in this government be wanting to cover up something relating to the Hilton bombing?

Reflect back to what happened. The actions that would be investigated by various inquiries, royal commissions or whatever would relate to the Fraser Liberal government, ASIO and the then Commonwealth police 20 years ago. To suggest that somehow or other their actions cause some embarrassment to the present Attorney-General, to me or to anyone else is ludicrous in the extreme. I have always taken the view that it would be no skin off my nose, or the nose of the present Attorney-General, if there were any convincing reasons to justify having a royal commission.

The other interesting thing which I would like people to reflect on for a moment is what it would achieve. When you start with the view that ASIO was involved, because it was common knowledge, as was put by the previous speaker, is anyone going to believe what comes out of a royal commission? I know what would happen if there were a royal commission, whether it were run by New South Wales or whatever. People would not believe it, because people like the conspiracy theory: they wallow in it and they will go on believing it forever.

It is also worth recalling that the activities of ASIO in relation to those events of February 1978 have, in one way or another, been subject to five different inquiries already—not to the wide extent that the speakers here this morning want, I concede. The first one was the New South Wales coronial inquest in 1982. The second one was the Hope Royal Commission into Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies in 1984. The third one was the Woods inquiry into the conviction of the so-called `Yagoona Three' in 1984-85. The fourth one, the most recent inquiry to touch on ASIO's activities around the time of the bombing, was the report by the previous Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security into certain complaints against ASIO by Mr Richard Seary.

The Attorney-General tabled that report in this parliament on 29 June. I doubt very much whether any of the speakers in this debate have read the report of the previous Inspector-General very carefully. They may be able to refute that, but I have grave doubts.

During that inquiry, the Inspector-General examined ASIO's intelligence holdings relating to the Hilton bombing to the extent that they were relevant to Mr Seary's complaints. If he had found evidence of complicity by ASIO in the Hilton bombing he would surely have said so in his report, but he did not. On the contrary, he said, `ASIO received no clear warning that the Hilton bombing was going to occur,' and, `From what I have read and heard, the organisation was genuinely shocked at the bombing.' That appears at pages 27 and 58 of the report tabled by the Attorney-General in this parliament.

It is this government's considered view after a lot of examination—I can assure those people who are interested in it this morning—that no information has been put before us which would justify a royal commission. Certainly, there has been nothing put before this parliament this morning. None of the evidence put before the government so far or that can be derived from available records indicates that any Commonwealth government agencies involved in the security arrangements for that meeting in February 1978 acted in a manner other than in the proper discharge of their functions and duties. That is the conclusion that we have come to after much investigation.

The allegations that have cropped up, which Mr Haviland and Mr Abbott went through, of a conspiracy or work of ASIO—the failure to employ sniffer dogs, the disposal of the remains of the bomb, the conduct of subsequent investigations and so on—are all matters, every single one of them, clearly within the responsibility and authority of the government of New South Wales. They were and still are.

If the New South Wales government wants to have that royal commission, then that is a matter for it; we cannot stop that—and do not want to, may I repeat. But what I am saying is that all of these matters have been examined very carefully. If you go back through the Hansard and look at the answers that have been given, you will see that we have attempted to deal with these issues item by item, in particular in relation to the questions put by the member for North Sydney. They were extremely detailed questions. They are not questions that any Attorney-General at any time could have ignored in any way, and they were not. Hours and hours were put into the answers. No-one is complaining about that. There was no evidence to justify what the member for North Sydney was alleging.

I will make a couple of points on that. Under the division of responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the New South Wales agencies, the Commonwealth, through ASIO, provided threat assessments. As for physical security, when we talk about the question of the rubbish bin, for example, the New South Wales police had the responsibility for security outside the Hilton Hotel, including George Street. It was not the Commonwealth; it was a New South Wales Police responsibility.

A number of people, including Mr Haviland this morning, in order to justify an inquiry, keep repeating as a fact the myth that ASIO conspired to plant a bomb in some deranged plot to force the Fraser government to recognise the importance of security agents and agencies and thereby increase their funding. The fact of that matter is that the truth is always more prosaic.

When you look at it in this instance, you see that it was not some deranged plot by ASIO that caused that to happen. It was the 1979 act and budget which arose out of the recommendations of the Hope royal commission, which were submitted to the Fraser government in 1977. If you look at the speech of Mr Fraser to parliament on 25 October 1978, you see that he puts this beyond doubt. The then Liberal government accepted Mr Justice Hope's recommendations and intended to act on them. If the decision to revise the ASIO Act and to increase ASIO's resources predates the bombing, then what rational motive could there be for ASIO to plant the bomb for that reason? That issue had been disposed of before that date. So that is not something that hangs together in any rational way.

People are concerned about these matters. We understand that. There are allegations that arise which have always been examined very carefully and have been answered in the most extensive detail. If you go through the Hansard and look at the answers and the work that has gone into it, you will see that we are still of the view that there is no need, no requirement, to have a new inquiry. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) is to be congratulated for bringing this motion before the House. The motion is supported by the Premier of New South Wales and unanimously by the New South Wales parliament. It is a motion undoubtedly supported by the majority of the people of Australia. The Premier of New South Wales is to be particularly congratulated for following through on the unanimous decision of the New South Wales parliament in 1991 asking the federal government to agree to a joint federal-state inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The New South Wales Premier's recent action of making state files available to the public on the Hilton bombing is a breath of fresh air after years of deliberate frustration of any attempt to find the truth, although anyone who has followed the 17-year saga of conspiracy of public officials to avoid accountability will not be surprised to see the Premier's good intentions white-anted.

Some might superficially ask: what is the point of trying to reopen a 17-year-old affair which has already been worked over by a major inquiry, several court cases, many reports and thousands of media reports? The fact is that the Hilton bombing is the worst act of political terrorism in this country's history. It was the largest security operation ever mounted in Australia, involving all key security agencies. It was also the most outrageous failure of security in Australian history, yet no-one responsible for the security operation has ever been held to account.

Dozens of organisations and hundreds of highly paid experts stood by while a bomb in the most obvious place, the main entrance of the Hilton, exploded—a bomb in a litter bin in the entrance of the Hilton, which had been ignored for many hours before the blast in spite of it being in the most obvious place to check. The sniffer dogs, carefully trained for weeks for the specific purpose of security at the Hilton, would have found the bomb instantly, yet they were prevented from going to the site just at the critical time.

However, no-one is accountable, and a succession of federal governments and ministers, over 17 years, have protected those responsible for this horrendous security failure. Never once in all the court cases and inquiries have any of those responsible for the security of the Hilton given any explanation or been forced to be accountable. Instead, we have had an endless succession of inquiries and millions of dollars of public money wasted, with no hope of finding the truth.

That is one of the reasons why the pressure for a genuine inquiry into the Hilton bombing will not stop—and it will not stop, until justice is delivered to those who died or were injured in the bombing. Three people were convicted of the crime, and later the same three were acquitted. Another is now in gaol on the same set of evidence which freed the other three.

This government has been avoiding the truth for 12 years. It is inconceivable that there exists one shred of justification in the pretence that calling the Commonwealth agencies and individuals to account for their actions 17 years ago could in any way prejudice security today. It can only have the opposite effect. The conclusion is inescapable: that the massive security failure at the Hilton was either breathtaking incompetence and negligence, or it has a more sinister explanation—or both.

I regret to say that the present Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has continued the pattern of being a ministerial captive of the bureaucrats. His recent statements to Terry Griffiths, who has devoted 17 years to obtaining justice, are little short of contemptible. He has attempted to belittle Griffiths's efforts by implying that there is futility and pointlessness in going on about the Hilton; and he has insulted Griffiths's intelligence by constantly referring him back to the New South Wales authorities, when he is aware of the futility of a New South Wales inquiry being held without genuine Commonwealth cooperation. The Attorney-General should get some untainted advice from sources other than those in the bureaucracies and on his own staff with a vested interest.

The pretence that continuing secrecy is synonymous with the effective operation of security and intelligence agencies and in the public interest but that exposing the truth about the Hilton is not is a chilling reinforcement of the public perception of the arrogance of this government. It only adds to the cancerous erosion of faith in the public institutions of this country which, alone, will probably result in a change of government at the next election.

I have asked some 70 questions in this House about the Hilton bombing. The answers have been grudging, evasive, on occasions wrong and permeated with a `neither confirm nor deny' mantra. Yet what information has been gleaned has only added more questions and more doubts. There were hundreds of people in the bureaucracies and security agencies involved to some degree in the Hilton, and many of those have played a part in blocking inquiries ever since.
The recent Holdich report simply raises more questions. All that report has done is reinforce the view recently put forward by the Premier of New South Wales when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: This wouldn't be the only time in history when a security agency has been engaged in a conspiracy to get more attention for itself or an elevated role for itself . . .

The Holdich report whitewashing ASIO is an insult to the public. The Attorney-General's acceptance of this report makes him an accomplice. The government and the Attorney-General are now isolated on this issue. The public, the New South Wales parliament, the Premier of New South Wales and the media—as would a majority of this House if a free vote were ever permitted—support a full and proper inquiry into the Hilton and the motion before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Mrs B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to talk about an area of the law which I think is not often thought of or discussed by people, unless they are directly affected by it—and it is in the area of corporations law. I talk about the concept of class orders and the way that they operate to, indeed, change the Corporations Law. This is a matter with which I have been concerned for some time, because it relates to the way in which corporations, in their annual reports, report transactions with related third parties.

PARA.TAB: I was prompted to think of this because of a report in this morning's paper that the piggery that was formerly owned by Mr Keating and his associates has now been totally sold offshore—with the final share from his former partner Mr Constantinidis being sold to, it is said, Singapore interests.

I am interested in this matter because of the fact that, if there had not been a class order granted back in 1993, there would have been a requirement on the bank to report on the relationship between Mr Keating and the Commonwealth Bank and the nature of the loans he had from that bank. I am further concerned about this matter because, on the last day before the last election in 1993, a document dated 6 August 1992 in the name of D.N. Maynard of the Commonwealth Bank, purporting to be a report to the credit committee of the board, was the subject of a legal action by the Commonwealth Bank to prevent this document being published by Channel 10. It was an interim injunction that was sought and was gained. The action came back before the court on the following Tuesday, when—surprise, surprise—nobody was interested in debating it any further.

Accounting standards are of particular importance in the corporations law when you look at what happened in the 1980s and the lack of material that was available. You could say the background accounting standards, which apply to corporations on related party transaction disclosure, were developed to meet a perceived inadequacy of information available in annual reports to shareholders of activities of directors with companies they controlled. It was felt that disclosure of information required by this accounting standard would prevent the recurrence of the excesses of the 1980s. Thus we have accounting standards AAS22 and AASB1017 concerning related party transactions.

Class orders had been obtained which effectively exempted directors and auditors from reporting on related party disclosures. This could be for quite sensible reasons: that is, it could involve spouses' Bankcard accounts or private small savings accounts—that sort of thing—which is very sensible. But there was a distinction to be made between, I believe, commercial banks and a government business enterprise—namely, the Commonwealth Bank.

In 1993, under the guidelines for financial statements of public authorities and commercial activities, which were issued by the Minister for Finance, it was said with regard to Accounting Standard AAS22 on related party transactions that `subject to Ministers not being taken to be related parties in relation to matters falling within their statutory responsibilities, they were to be exempted'. But in all other respects, ministers of the executive government were to be related parties for all public authorities and Commonwealth commercial entities. That is quite clearly meant to cover the Commonwealth Bank.

Accounting Standard 1017 was amended. It was amended in order to toughen it up so that we could have a stronger accounting system. Immediately that amendment was gazetted, there was a letter written by the Australian Bankers Association to the Australian Securities Commission, asking for an expedited and amended class order to be given in respect of reporting on related third-party transactions. The worrying thing was that the conclusion of the letter says this:

SPEECH.PARA: It is therefore submitted that there is an overwhelming case for the ASC to extend the scope of the Class Order in the terms sought. If you wish any further information or explanation in support of the application please call—
and a man is named—
of Commonwealth Bank of Australia—
and the phone number is given. It continues:

Because the financial year of Commonwealth Bank of Australia ends on June 30 1993, it is anxious to have the benefit of the ASC's ruling on the extended Class Order as soon as possible. Other member banks of the Australian Bankers' Association are similarly affected by the disclosure requirements but their financial years occur later in the calendar.
Quite clearly this letter was written at the behest of the Commonwealth Bank with regard to expediting the granting of the extended class order because of their reporting period.

PARA.TAB: Last week we had a public hearing of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. In the course of that hearing Mr Cameron, from the Australian Securities Commission, and legal counsel appeared before that committee. I asked the legal counsel, Mr Durbridge, who had drafted the class order giving the exemption, whether or not it had been brought to his attention that there was indeed a connection between Mr Keating and the Commonwealth Bank.

That document I referred to which had been subject to the injunction was in fact very much in the public domain. That document—the authenticity of which we know to be true because the Commonwealth Bank sought legal relief from it being published, and it was successful—shows one P. Keating to be a director-principal of the piggery group of companies. It also showed that there was a provision being made by the bank for the possibility of forgiving $4.5 million worth of the debt owed by that group of piggeries. This is contemporaneous with the Commonwealth Bank shutting down small farmers and small businesses. It is of concern that we have not had correct reporting on these matters.

So I would go back to the guidelines of the Minister for Finance, which indeed require ministers to be accountable when they are acting other than in the capacity of their duty as a minister. I do not believe that Mr Keating's investment in the piggery group of companies had anything to do with his ministerial responsibilities. I found it of deep concern, as did Mr Durbridge, when he answered my question by saying that had he known about the connection he certainly would have been at least hesitant and would have looked far more stringently at the application for the class order granting relief.

As I said, this series of events opens a large number of questions. These documents have been in the public arena, there are many questions being asked and I think it is time that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) gave some answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is somewhat timely that my opportunity on the grievance debate occurs during National Hearing and Deafness Awareness Week. I note the announcement by the parliamentary secretary of the release of a video entitled It won't come back. I also note the fact that there is a lot of publicity about issues for the hearing impaired and the deaf during this period.

PARA.TAB: I want to raise the issue of the captioning of television in this country. They essentially show the soundtrack of television or video programs in a process whereby video captions are visible with an ordinary VCR showing the actual words in different colours so that people can distinguish the speakers. We had estimates in 1993 that as many as 999,800 people in this country have hearing loss or partial hearing loss—nearly one million people, according to the Bureau of Statistics, in 1993. So we are talking about a significant number of people.

I put on the record an indication of the experience of people who suffer from these problems. One of my constituents, Mr Nicholas Tayeh, who has been a constant campaigner on this matter, says of his son's experience:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as the father of a 22 year old profoundly deaf son, I know being deaf is a most unpleasant disability. The isolation that results from it can lead to depression which, in all its forms—insomnia, irritability etc.—can affect employment, lifestyle, social and family life, and that worries me very much. Being able to re-establish lines of communication and being up to date with current events can help break this vicious cycle of isolation and depression and help deaf people, especially the young deaf people, not to give up!

Mr Tayeh has, on a number of occasions, raised this matter. I put on record appreciation for people like Senator Hill, former Senator Sowada and Senator Bourne, who have also in this parliament raised with the government this issue and the need for the government to be a bit more pro-active with regard to finance.

PARA.TAB: The aim of the National Working Party on Captioning, which was established in December 1991, is that by 2010 all programs on Australian TV networks will be captioned. Its aim for the immediate term is that by the year 2000 all government videos will be captioned. The Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations has some very nice wording in their code of practice. They say they seek to ensure that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . closed-captioned programs are clearly indicated in program information—
big deal because we do not have many of them. They will also:
endeavour to increase the amount of closed-captioned programming, in consultation with organisations representing hearing-impaired and deaf viewers.

Substantially, very few programs are captioned—Lateline, the occasional documentary and some dramas. In actual fact, only 7 1/2 per cent of national television is captioned at the moment. These people have a long way to go to accomplish anything near what they seek. There has been captioning since 1982, mainly in the government television sector. There has been the occasional $5,000 from FACTS. In 1994-95, $231,000 was allocated by the government for video captioning and ABC Lateline and a further half a million dollars came from the ABC.

PARA.TAB: There have been various excuses for not captioning more—there is some, I guess, validity in them—which include that we do not have a national news, as various states do their own localised news reporting, and therefore the cost in this country would not be comparable to Canada or the US. But it is still not good enough that ABC television captions only 20 hours a week, and that is half of the national effort. The ABC endeavour is half of what we do nationally. It is still not good enough that we have captioning for only 7 1/2 per cent of all programs.

There have been, as I say, a number of references to overseas situations. The BBC is currently captioning 28 hours each week, on BBC1 and BBC2. These are all national bulletins, and the BBC has plans to be captioning regional bulletins by next year. Four years ago it was captioning no news at all. ITV in England currently captions 14 hours of news each week. In the United States and Canada more and more cable stations are providing captioning. Virtually every free to air television station broadcasting news in the USA provides some news captioning service. So things are happening internationally.

There have been estimates of the cost of a hybrid style of captioning. These figures indicate that this matter should be put a lot higher on the agenda in this country. There has unfortunately been a bit of buck shoving between the human services portfolio and the communications department in regards to getting anything done on this matter.

Amongst the options suggested were four variations for news captioning of the ABC news. The one-off establishment cost under one scheme is as low as $268,000. The highest estimate cost for an alternative is a bit over a million dollars. Ongoing costs would be approximately $1.2 million to $1.5 million. This would be of value to nearly one million Australians. In looking at the amounts of money devoted to other requirements in this country, I really think we have to question our priorities.

There has been a degree of government action on the matter. The government's national conference in 1994 in Hobart carried a resolution which stated that Labor will fund services and programs that promote a competent and positive image of people with disabilities and ensure their lifestyles are as similar as possible to those of the general community where possible through a process of integration. Labor supports the provision of subtitling of news and current affairs on ABC and SBS television. So there was a commitment to do something about this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if you can't get SBS?
—Fortunately, the stretch of SBS is extremely significant in this country. I am not sure whether you can get it personally, but I do not really think it is that relevant.

PARA.TAB: Captioning has also been found in a number of the United States studies to be extremely useful for children with learning disabilities and for those people attempting to learn English. The University of Maryland surveyed comparative groups in both of those classes and found that there was a very quantitative and real ability to improve their skills. A study commissioned by the National Captioning Institute in the United States in regard to those learning English as a second language concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: In the 12-week study conducted in Lowell, Massachusetts . . . in all cases, `students watching closed-captioned television scored higher on a number of written tests than any of the other treatment groups'.
That was a statement from Temple University professor Dr Susan Neuman, the chief researcher on the study. She said:
They were better able to understand word meaning and pronunciation, recognise spellings and grasp onto concepts much more quickly than by reading alone.

It is not just the reality of nearly one million Australians who have been seriously deprived of information, who are struggling to know what is going on around them and who are deprived of opportunities for knowledge and pleasure; it is these other groups.

PARA.TAB: Subtitles are needed because deaf and hearing impaired people need to have access to correct information at the same time as hearing people. They need to learn about the world through TV as they are unable to hear the radio. They have the right to know what is going on, from international situations to federal politics and through a range of local issues. They should be able to rely on more than just the newspapers to get a view on issues. Increasingly in this country the monopolisation of the media makes that an even more imperative move.

It is about time, particularly during National Hearing and Deafness Awareness Week, that this government stopped worrying about whether this or that minister can pass the letter over to the other minister and whether we can have further delays to make sure that nothing occurs. The option for captioning in Australian television and the bringing in of money to this very much needed area is overdue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne Mr C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the days on Tin Pan Alley, the music industry has been famous for its shonky deals and rip-offs. I suppose it is only appropriate that a government led by an old rock and roller, Bankstown's answer to Andrew Loog Oldham, should be continuing this tradition. In Australia it does not matter if you are into Mozart, Miles or Max Sharam or, for that matter, Mahler—you are paying too much for compact discs.

PARA.TAB: When it made the decision to maintain import controls on CDs in April this year, the government decided to continue to force Australian consumers to pay CD prices of up to $9 more than in overseas markets. It abandoned five years worth of efforts to tackle the overpriced music market and made a decision that ignored local consumers and only benefited the tiny handful of multinationals—EMI, Sony, BMG, Warners and Polygram—that dominate the recording industry.

Of course, music lovers are not the only people who will be paying more under this policy. It will also affect would-be purchasers of books and computer software. We are told that this decision is vital to ensure a vibrant Australian music industry, to protect our cultural identity and prevent our domination by overseas sounds.

It is a great irony that this government, with all its republican pretensions, has based its decision around laws that stem from the days of the British empire. The big record companies originally won their import monopoly under laws we adapted years ago from British legislation designed to protect the monopoly of British publishers in what were then called colonial markets.

Back in 1990, the Prices Surveillance Authority found that international recording companies were slugging local consumers for CDs, compared with prices charged in the US and in Europe. Australian CD prices were consistently higher, sometimes up to 40 per cent. The PSA recommended that parallel importing be allowed as it would result in significantly reduced prices for consumers. As a result of this, the cabinet agreed in June 1992 to amend the Copyright Act to allow the parallel importation of new release sound recordings by foreign artists from five Western countries from 1 July 1994. Despite opposition from the industry, legislation to implement this move was introduced in December 1992 but it lapsed with the dissolution of the parliament before the 1993 election. The record companies claimed in their defence that they needed to charge high prices for imported CDs to finance the cost of publishing Australian performers. However, the PSA also found that companies did not appear to be spending significantly to develop local talent.

The recording giants then argued that parallel importing would increase piracy. This is despite the fact that the biggest piracy problems they experience in Australia come from locally produced product. They tried to use intellectual property law before finally settling for the argument that the government's proposed package of reforms was contrary to GATT. This was then backed up by a submission from the Attorney-General's Department arguing that excluding Australian artists from parallel importation was in effect a protectionist measure unsustainable in the new world trading environment that had evolved since the 1992 decision was made.

The reversal of the 1992 decision came the same week or the week after agreement was reached on the Hilmer reforms. The government suddenly became very selective over which micro-economic reforms and competition reforms it actually wanted. Rather than opening up the music industry in the way GATT had intended, the government used GATT as an excuse to return to the bad old days.

Over recent years the government has developed a very cosy relationship with the arts community, a group that has been credited with providing crucial votes at the last election. The arts lobby was well rewarded last year with $250 million in the Creative Nation package. Offering further recompense through import protection on music has surely stretched generosity to the limit, especially when we consider who the real beneficiaries have been. It was interesting to read the comments of a buyer for a chain of music stores in the Sydney Telegraph Mirror just before the government's decision was announced. The spokesperson said:

SPEECH.PARA: We pay extremely high prices—they are much more expensive than in America. The record companies are very powerful in this country and this will keep the power in their hands.
The Australian Consumers Association Chief Executive, Louise Sylvan, echoed this view at the same time when she said:

The government ought to be given a Grammy Award for its indecisive performance in this area of microeconomic reform. . . Having decided in 1992 to ensure a better deal for consumers by deregulating import provisions, the government is now set to go into reverse gear.

Ms Sylvan told media representatives the background was `a product of the intense lobbying of the multinational record companies'. She said that Australian consumers deserve better than this from their own government. Another ACA spokesperson, Gail Kennedy, said it was unfair that Australians were deprived of access to reasonably priced CDs. She told journalists that CDs—and I quote:

. . . are so much cheaper in other countries and it's not fair that the current price disparity is maintained . . . the price disparity between Australia and overseas is pretty tough—there is a marked difference, a very generous gap. That's a tough thing for consumers to accept—they shouldn't have to.
Ms Kennedy also pointed out the ridiculousness of the restriction at a time when the government is supposedly trying to introduce more competition to other industries. She said:

If we are supposed to be pushing for a level playing field, consumers of CDs must be wondering which end of the field they are on. When we are supposed to have a policy of producing competitive industries, how can this be justified?

PARA.TAB: Even the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) was concerned about the decision. A cabinet submission stated her belief that `the 1992 decision and public commitment to allow parallel importing is in the best interests of consumers and should stand'. She went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . CD prices remain too high, even if the differentials [in price between the US and Australia] have narrowed, and that consumer groups and the general public are likely to vigorously challenge the claim that the price of CDs has fallen.

If I have quoted at length, it is only because there is simply no excuse for the way in which the government has acted on this matter. There has never been any `ground up' review of the recording industry and how it serves Australia's economic interests. There has been no independent review by the Industry Commission, or even an internal review by the Bureau of Industry Economics. We simply have no idea what ministers and their advisers and officials have based their recommendations and final decisions on.

PARA.TAB: The industry has claimed that, by paying higher prices for offerings from established acts, local consumers are helping fund and foster the development of new Australian talent. But, at the same time, it likes to claim that the price gap with comparable markets has shrunk. This argument is entirely self-defeating. If there is no longer any significant price difference, the existing arrangements obviously cannot be generating any significant subsidies for the development of local product.

There has already been a considerable amount of discussion over direct government assistance to the music industry. At least this sort of measure would be transparent and would provide a level of accountability when opposed to the entirely self-serving and sanctimonious arguments its representatives use to justify their current approach.

Finally, we will do well to remember that most Australian artists—like much innovative music the world over—have been developed by independent promoters and recording companies. If these companies were allowed to compete for distribution business and gain more commercial strength, they would do an even better job promoting our new performers.

Past Australian consumption of recorded music has been low by international standards because of high costs. Simple laws of supply and demand suggest that, if CDs were more fairly priced, the recording industries would benefit as consumers would buy more product. This government's policy favours the music establishment and it penalises consumers. It especially hits young consumers—people with limited cash to spend, but the groups that would be crucial in breaking new acts—so, ultimately, this policy is self-defeating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of bank fees and charges is of vital concern to families in my electorate of Lilley and throughout Australia. The recent PSA inquiry into bank fees and charges concluded that the present fee regime is mis-skewed. I would go much further than that. I believe that some banks have set out to drive lower income earners out of the banking system altogether.

PARA.TAB: The banks claim that they are like other retailers. But what butcher, baker or supermarket would put a neon sign at the front of their shops flashing `low income earners not welcome'? And, for instance, if you were in a supermarket and decided to buy a jar of vegemite, you would not get the price jacked up just because you did not turn up with a trolley full of goods. The banks are clearly not behaving like other retailers with their fees and charges.

Fortunately for the Australian public, the PSA exposed the banks' hysterical pseudo propaganda about the cost of running no-frills accounts. The PSA was unequivocal in rejecting the main plank of the banks' argument when it said, `There is no direct link between the cost of the account and the amount of money in the account.' The PSA went on to say that it was possible for the banks to provide satisfactory no-frills accounts and that already there are some bank accounts that come close to that objective.

Opponents of no-frills accounts describe those who advocate the accounts' introduction as calling for free banking. We are doing no such thing. Nothing could be further from the truth. Advocates of no-frills accounts want a basic banking account which will serve people on lower incomes and not cost those individuals or families an arm and a leg to operate.

We are talking about a basic banking product where there is a limited number of free or minimal cost transactions per month. We are not saying that other customers should be massively subsidising someone who wants to go to the bank and withdraw $5 over the counter every day for a fortnight. We are not suggesting that at all.

When we talk about a no-frills account we are talking about no fees as long as the basic banking product limits are not exceeded by the customer. We are talking about, perhaps, no interest if the essential basic banking product is provided. We are talking about customers being limited to one basic banking product and no other transaction accounts. We are definitely talking about universal access.

We are talking about a product that people can access legitimately at minimal cost. We are not proposing that people should be able to abuse the system by turning up every day and withdrawing $1. We are not saying that at all. We are not talking about free banking. We are talking about fair and reasonable access.

In the banking system to date the existing structure of fees and charges has been particularly hurting pensioners and families, who rarely have a minimum bank balance of $500. There are not that many families I know of that carry a minimum balance of $500 as they struggle to make ends meet and bring up their children; the situation is similar, the people on the basic rate of pension.

The PSA report places the onus fairly and squarely on banks to stop hiding behind the fake figures they have been presenting to the public. Probably no organisation in the banking industry has been more guilty of this approach, I say sadly, than the Commonwealth Bank. Some time ago the banks put about an argument that was really Alice in Wonderland stuff. They came up with the claim that the establishment of a basic banking product account would cost the banks and the community $1 billion a year. It was simply unbelievable and incredible. What were they proposing would come with the account? Champagne for every dollar handed across? Caviar? It was clearly nonsense and has been clearly exposed as nonsense by the PSA report.

As I said earlier, probably no bank has been more guilty of that approach than the Commonwealth Bank. Mr David Murray, the Chairman of the Australian Bankers Association and the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, had this to say at a recent Bankers Association dinner:

SPEECH.PARA: The argument—
about bank fees and charges—
has been allowed to focus on issues such as our margins, such as our social responsibility. . .
Shock, horror! How terrible it is that the public should be debating bank margins and social responsibility.

PARA.TAB: The fact is, Mr Murray, and all those other bankers out there, the argument has focused on the issues of margins, social responsibility and costs—and so it should. What does Mr Murray think we should be arguing about? The colour of the carpets in the banks? Really, what Mr Murray and many other bankers have been saying is that the banks are above scrutiny; that their figures should not be questioned.

Indeed, Mr Murray went on to say that arguments about margins, costs and social responsibility were red herrings. Well, they are not. The banks have tendered their costings based on a system which pretends that the cost of each transaction is the same and that, because they make more money from larger accounts than smaller accounts, somehow the larger accounts are subsidising the smaller accounts. It takes very little time in a bank to see that the average pensioner's transaction takes only the fraction of the time of someone bringing in the weekend takings.

The Commonwealth Bank has been particularly guilty of leading this propaganda charge and peddling a lot of misleading arguments. For example, the Commonwealth Bank claims that it gives exemptions from its fees and charges to pensioners. I thought that for a week or two myself, until I discovered that the Commonwealth Bank's exemptions do not apply to new pensioners.

If you were a pensioner as of tomorrow and walked into the Commonwealth Bank, you would not be exempt at all. Any new customer who goes into the Commonwealth Bank—say they receive a DSS age pension or a veteran's pension—will be hit by the fees, along with low income families, unemployed people, other pensioners and children with small accounts.

The problem is that the banks have set out to drive some of the less well off out of the banking system. What is to be done about it? Firstly, the public should not take out their frustrations on bank staff. They must address their concerns to management and the board. The policies of the board are not the responsibility of bank staff, who are doing their best to earn a living and provide for their families.

Secondly, the government, in the light of the PSA report, must consider a range of options in its policy development. One option for serious consideration is to amend the code of banking practice to provide a guarantee of access to banking services for all customers. Industry based codes are one of the best ways of ensuring a fair and flexible market for services. An amendment to the code requiring banks to provide affordable financial transaction accounts and a guarantee that all consumers have the right of access to such accounts would be one course of action.

If the ABA and other bankers are genuine, they would readily approach the government to begin discussions. Given the number of banks that have indicated privately to me and others, including the PSA, that they have no problems in bringing in a no-frills account, why will they not proceed forthwith? It would not be such a big step if they were to do what they say privately they are already doing.

I also believe that the acceptance of a code which is committed to a basic banking product, among other things, might well become a condition of receiving a banking licence. As a community, perhaps we should consider public hearings for licence issue and/or renewal. Certainly, given the recent experience with the Commonwealth Bank, the code should provide for effective notification procedures for fee charges and changes.

These are all matters that could be taken up in the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration. Some banks have clearly issued a deliberate challenge to the PSA and the government by acting against PSA recommendations and not moving towards introduction of a basic banking account.

But, of course, the banks are not on their own. The opposition shares their view. The opposition thinks that the existing level of fees and charges is fine. Its philosophy on tax is that the lower your income the higher the amount of tax you pay, and the higher your income the lower the amount of tax you pay. Of course, that is the whole philosophy behind the existing structure of bank fees and charges. If the Australian people are looking to the opposition for action on this, then, as in so many other areas, they can forget it.

I am committed—and I am sure many members of this government are committed—to ensuring that low income families and pensioners get a fair go, and are not driven out of the banking system—and that we have a banking system which pays appropriate heed to the whole concept of social responsibility, fairness and equity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest Mr J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will hold the member for Lilley (Mr Swan) to his commitment to ensure that we see a better performance and better practices from banks. Part of what I want to say relates to that very subject from a different perspective. I speak on behalf of people who are going without and on behalf of the needy. I am particularly aggrieved at the continuing lack of consideration the government provides to my electorate.

PARA.TAB: I have been a member of this parliament for a little longer than two years now, patiently waiting for some sort of consideration for the desperate people I represent in the Wimmera-Mallee. There are a number of matters I could mention, but none epitomises the government's neglect more than the refusal to grant exceptional circumstances drought assistance to Victoria.

Both the Mallee and Wimmera regions of my electorate are heavily dependent on the agriculture that surrounds them. In fact, agriculture is the very source of the local economy. When things are bad for agriculture, it flows right through the economic sector. It follows that small businesses in the service sector suffer equally cruelly when agriculture is on its knees. This means that there are many families in small businesses who are added to the already large number of farming families who are going without—the very same sort of people the member for Lilley was referring to in his remarks.

There has already been a decade of extremely poor commodity prices which has created an unbelievably heavy debt load and financial burden. Add to this a period of unprecedentedly high interest rates created by deliberate government policy and you have the current dire circumstances experienced by many of the families in my electorate.

On top of that whole decade of difficulty, add another three failed seasons in a row. The first of these seasons was because of excessive rainfall right in the middle of the harvest in 1992-93. It actually ruined what would have been a good harvest. The second was because of a mouse plague in 1993-94 which ate the crop before it even had a chance to grow. These are the difficulties and challenges faced by people who work the land. The third was because of the record drought in 1994-95, which I am addressing.

The financial strain of excessive borrowing to cope with all these failed seasons has been intolerable. The member for Lilley spoke about banks and banking practices. Sadly, there are now far too many families in my electorate being crushed under the heel and the demand of banks wanting to sell them up. Small business, as well as the farming sector, has suffered the same fate.The financial hardship and despair all this has generated leaves a huge number of people I represent completely disillusioned about the good intentions of the current government. They are fairly determined and resilient folk, but they wonder how many more times they are going to be slapped in the face and denied their genuine requests for assistance.

My electorate is one of the 16th poorest electorates represented in this chamber. The member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) earlier today made reference to poverty. My electorate is no different. The nearest formal statistics for Mallee I have relate to the 1991 census. They are bad enough, but things have deteriorated since. A staggering 23.2 per cent of families in Mallee have annual incomes of less than $16,000 per annum. The members in this House ought to consider how they could survive trying to educate their children through to tertiary education, paying for their expenses to attend schools in metropolitan centres, yet being denied access to Austudy because of their perceived wealth in assets while having incomes as low as $16,000 per annum and lower. It is not a very wealthy electorate in terms of total income. Only 7.7 per cent have family incomes in excess of $60,000 per annum. These are 1991 statistics, but I can assure you that anecdotal evidence suggests that things have deteriorated since then.

Mallee has the 12th lowest median family income—an average of $26,585 per annum. These are appalling statistics. Is it any wonder the socioeconomic fabric of many families is falling down around their ears? It does not give me much joy to stand here in this place and bring these facts before the parliament, but it needs to be done.

It is with this background that I would have thought the government would have given a much more favourable consideration to Victoria's application for drought assistance. Not one senior minister visited the north-west of Victoria to inspect personally the hardship being experienced. Although the government did send out the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Nick Sherry, and I appreciated his visit, it was well after the event. Many of my people have asked me to ask the government and those who sit on the government benches: do you really care?

The government says it relies heavily on the report of the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Committee, RASAC, which recommended refusal of Victoria's application. Up until half an hour ago, the government was refusing to make that report available as a public document. They have since done so, and I have a copy with me. It is very interesting reading through this report. It seems inconceivable to me that the report would say that major droughts in Victoria in 1967-68 and in 1982-83, according to the current criteria to assess exceptional circumstances, would not be severe droughts.

The member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) would remember, as I do, the droughts of 1968 and 1982. These were substantial droughts. Who will forget those unbelievable dust storms which engulfed many of our capital cities, and have since been immortalised in postcards and calendar photographs? Remember those rolling dust storms. They were the droughts of 1968 and 1982. Yet the criteria used to assess Victoria's drought application would say that those were not severe droughts. I am bitterly disappointed.

The social and economic decline of my electorate after a decade of Labor with its high interest policies and its lack of decency and consideration has decimated my patch. The strain on social welfare is starting to show. There is a plethora of welfare groups in my electorate. I was recently approached by the local corps of the Salvation Army from Swan Hill. It is a very sad day when we have come to rely on voluntary agencies like the Salvation Army to provide welfare aid, but that is a reality. Determined, proud people have been reduced to come cap in hand, humiliated, to ask for charity.

I have a letter here from an officer of the Swan Hill Corps, Lieutenant Mick Gray. He advises me that the government has reduced its aid to needy families across Australia by reducing the allocation to the Salvation Army relief fund by a staggering 25 per cent. What this means for Lieutenant Gray is that he now has about $5,000 left to meet the needs of the north-west of Victoria, which his corps services. He advises me in his letter:

SPEECH.PARA: As the region's major provider of welfare relief, I struggle to see that it will be possible to continue to provide the level of service to this district as these funds will run out in November/December.
He urges me further:
Therefore, we would request that you intervene on our behalf with our Federal Parliament with the view to obtaining further funding for the Salvation Army in the Swan Hill area.

I am doing just that as part of this grievance. I add to the remarks made earlier in the day by the member for Hinkler, who has drawn this urgency to the attention of the House. Nowhere is it being harder felt than in the Mallee region of the north-west of Victoria. Hardworking, honest people are reduced to asking the government for help, despite a history of determined independence and resilience. That is how desperate things have got. I am urging the government to give far better and decent consideration to the desperate people of north-west Victoria.
