TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in debate today to again record, as I have done on numerous occasions since I became a member of this parliament in 1990, the concerns of my constituents regarding the construction of the Badgerys Creek airport and to put the facts before the parliament so that they will be recorded out there in the electorate at large, instead of some of the misinformation that seems to be going around now.

PARA.TAB: In recent times I have both attended and addressed airport meetings within the Prospect electorate regarding the proposed airport. In doing so, I have listened to the concerns of my constituents and conveyed to the ministers those concerns that my constituents are expressing. Most of the concerns are, at this stage, lack of knowledge of the flight paths and the direction which they will take, even though repeated assurances have been given, following investigations and studies into noise, water pollution and contours, that this will take place. The ensuing debate is now around the curfew and the concerns that people have that this is going to be a non-curfew airport, and therefore they are going to have jets going over at 2, 3 and 4 o'clock in the morning.

This came to mind today because there was an article in today's Telegraph stating that the Kingsford-Smith airport can no longer cope with more flights and that it looks like we are going to have to move posthaste with Badgerys Creek. I know this is a commitment that our government has given time and time again.

Most importantly, some of the misinformation that is going around is from some of the citizen action groups. I particularly acknowledge and always defend the right of all people to come together in meetings to demonstrate, talk, debate or at least have their grievances heard. I am particularly concerned when I find in my local newspaper as of yesterday that certain so-called citizens of my community, even though I know these particular citizens do not live in my community, state that it must be remembered that the federal opposition has now promised to complete an environmental impact statement if it wins the next election.

This person, Ms Vella, knows this is incorrect. To make sure the facts are getting across, I think it is about time we start having them, once again, brought into this parliament. We do know that some journalists—I say `some journalists'—do not like to have the facts stand in the way of a good story. But I think what they have to do is acknowledge when people make outrageous statements such as this and at least on occasion check their facts. I will give you some facts. Fact No. 1 is Howard's Report of July 1995 to all Bennelong residents. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Coalition will also ensure the construction of the new airport at Badgery's Creek to international level as a matter of priority. Unlike the Government, we appreciate the urgent need for a second Sydney Airport.
Furthermore, they have failed to adequately develop the second airport at Badgery's Creek despite giving this undertaking prior to the new runway's construction.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) went on to tell his constituents that the measures outlined by our Labor government in the budget to address the issues are grossly inadequate. Fact No. 2 relates to information of him going to go on, as quoted by a citizen in my electorate, with a full EIS. That is certainly contrary to what he wrote to Mr Geoff Grace, chairman of CRASH. A letter he addressed to Mr Grace on 9 July 1995 stated:

In relation to Sydney West (Badgery's Creek) Airport, the Coalition will ensure that the site is developed to full international standards as a matter of urgency. We appreciate the need for a second Sydney airport, particularly in light of the 2000 Olympics, and believe that in time, Sydney West Airport will have a major role in servicing the air traffic needs of the Sydney Basin.
It should be noted that The Badgery's Creek site was approved for development in late 1985. Despite repeated assurances to the contrary, the current Government—
meaning us—
has demonstrated a clear lack of commitment to this project and their intention to meet their recent Budget commitments must be reviewed with a great deal of scepticism.
That letter also referred to the bill the Leader of the Opposition had introduced in the parliament, but he went on to say about the government:

Through its failure to support my Bill, its plans to downgrade the east-west runway and its lack of commitment to the development of Sydney West Airport, the Government has once again demonstrated its inability to adequately deal with the long-term social and environmental problems associated with aircraft noise over Sydney.

I am repeating these facts because the citizens of the community are under the false impressions—I say `some citizens'; maybe they are apologists for the Liberal Party—that the coalition is concerned about people who live in western Sydney. The coalition is going to do a complete environmental impact statement, other than the one that was already done in 1985 and which our government has already given a commitment to supplement, to make sure that no airport development takes place until all that supplementation investigation has been carried out.

PARA.TAB: I go on to fact No. 3. That was on page 5 of the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 July. Obviously this reporter got the facts correct. The article states:
The Federal Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, rekindled political tensions yesterday over the third runway . . .

SPEECH.PARA: It went on to say:

PARA.TAB: However, he refused to make a commitment on key demands of airport protesters that Qantas be forced to move to Badgerys Creek and the number of aircraft movements into and out of Sydney Airport be capped.

SPEECH.PARA: He stated:

PARA.TAB: "We're pleading for a bit of old-fashioned fair go and that old-fashioned fair go demands that burden be shared around" . . .

SPEECH.PARA: We people in the west are demanding that bit of old-fashioned fair go. We are also demanding that the problems that are being experienced at the moment within the Kingsford Smith airport area will not be imposed on citizens in the west.

PARA.TAB: Fact No. 4 is from a door-stop interview that occurred in Sydney at 3.30 p.m. on 25 July. The Leader of the Opposition was asked by a journalist:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Howard, do you have a policy on an alternative airport? You got a bit of flak in there from one of your constituents, he said that you actually probably should say that Badgery's Creek should be alternative.
HOWARD:
But that is our policy.
It is an alternative. I now go to fact No. 5, from an interview with Clive Robertson at 2GB at 7.10 a.m. on 27 June. The interview goes:
ROBERTSON:
But if we are going to have three runways Mr Howard . . . means we might not need Badgerys?
HOWARD:

Well, I don't . . . I don't think that's right, I think there's a . . . the experience of the other cities is that . . . and particularly when you think of the volume of intra state traffic, that's the commuter air traffic, I think the volume is growing as such that the need for another airport is inescapable.
ROBERTSON:
. . . Have you seen the map indicating who's going to be affected by aeroplanes flying twenty four hours a day into Badgerys Creek?
HOWARD:

Well, I have seen all sorts of projections on that and they vary a bit according to who is making the projections but that obviously is a . . . is a debate and . . . that will have to be undertaken . . . a fight that'll have to be . . . be dealt with at the time . . . when the airport is opened . . .
I emphasise: take on a debate when the airport at Sydney West is opened.

I was only quoting from these documents because I wanted to make sure that I quoted correctly. It will give me great delight to make sure that it is tabled. By doing so, I can retain the transcripts that I have here, and I will not have to repeat another part of an interview which was given on Channel 10's news program at 5.03 p.m. on 1 February 1995. I will table that for the honourable member as well.

PARA.TAB: In that interview, a reporter stated that he raised at a public meeting an election promise and, after meeting with the opposition leader, the Marrickville mayor, Barry Cotter, said that Mr Howard had made some important undertakings. This is when Barry Cotter, the Mayor of Marrickville, stated that a `future Liberal government will reopen the east-west runway'. The second one is that they `support the fast tracking of Badgerys Creek airport under certain conditions'.

I have raised all of these points because there is misconception in my electorate and right across the south-west of Sydney regarding the Sydney West airport; there is misconception and misinformation. What the coalition is on about is a full environmental impact statement. I am saying to my constituents and to this parliament, as I have said time and time again, that what it is on about is the fast tracking of Badgerys Creek without any further investigations, studies or consultation with the people at large. That is not the commitment of the Labor government.

Our Labor government is committed to consultation with the people. Our Labor government has put some $23 million extra into a budget to make sure that environmental investigations and statements are carried out on noise, pollution and water. Our Labor government is committed to listening to the people. But we must have the correct facts. At every opportunity I have, I will continue to bring to the attention of this House—as I have already done in writing to both the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) and the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner—the concerns of my constituents and request a full investigation into those concerns.

One of the things which is viable in a community such as mine and right across Sydney's west is acknowledgment that, if Kingsford Smith can make a profit in running a curfew airport and closing in between the hours of 11 o'clock at night and 5 or 6 o'clock in the morning, surely to God, Badgerys Creek and the people in my community—who have built there and lived there, without having any knowledge, until the announcement was made in 1985, of an airport being proposed for that site—should have the right which has been given to those citizens in the inner city; that is, the right to have a sleeping environment in which the noise of aircraft coming in and taking off do not take place during the hours of 2, 3 and 4 o'clock in the morning. I think it is vital that my citizens have that assurance. I know that they are saying, `We're going to build the airport, which will be curfew free.' (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that, before I get another chance to speak in a grievance debate, an election will be upon us. Today most Australians know that something is wrong in this country, but they do not quite know what the problem is. However, what they do know is that their costs of living are rising and that a growing number of them are not able to meet their commitments.

PARA.TAB: In the 1990 election campaign some literature was distributed in my electorate saying, `Don't vote for the Liberals because they'll sell the Commonwealth Bank.' In 1995 it is not the Liberals who are selling the Commonwealth Bank but those across the track—those from the Labor Party who said that they would never sell it. This was not as the result of a lengthy debate in caucus but rather a fait accompli at 6.45 on the night the budget was being delivered. After the budget documents had been printed, it was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to the Labor caucus.

The coalition told the Australian people that it had no objections to the selling of the Commonwealth Bank. We were up-front and honest with the electorate. The Prime Minister, on the other hand, not only changed the line that had been presented to the Australian people but did not even allow his elected members to vote on the issue.

In 1993, when we presented a comprehensive taxation package to the electorate, the Prime Minister said, `This will be a referendum on taxation.' He categorically stated that there would be no new taxes and that would be l-a-w, law. The total taxation revenue in 1992-93, the last year before the 1993 election, was $89.435 billion, as shown on page 4.57 of this year's Budget Paper No. 1. In 1995-96, this financial year, the total taxation revenue has risen to $119.261 billion. That means this year alone, over and above the amount that would have been collected annually in 1992-93, an additional collection of $29.826 billion in taxation. So much for l-a-w, law.

In 1993, the wholesale sales tax collections were $9.25 billion. As of 1 July 1995, Australians will pay $14.16 billion in wholesale sales tax. That is about $785 per person per year or, for the average family of four, they will pay about $60 per week in wholesale sales tax out of their wages.

Unfortunately, the Australian consumer does not see where the wholesale sales tax is paid by the retailer, which is then added to the retail price. All the consumer knows is that the prices are going up. In 1993, the federal government collected $7.2 billion in fuel excise. This year they will collect $10.3 billion in fuel excise. In 1993, the Labor government told us they would reduce company tax to help businesses, yet in 1995-96 we have seen an increase of three per cent and the collection now of $17.14 billion.

This government has chosen to abuse the truth and abuse the responsibilities that are entrusted to it in this place. Governments in this place should be about presenting the facts and producing policies that will look after the interests of the people they represent, but this government has been about camouflaging the facts and printing distorted information that cannot be cross-referenced. It has been about providing grants in government seats, particularly in marginal seats, without the same provisions for opposition seats, as we saw in the sports rorts affair. We had to question this government week in, week out through debates in this place to reveal the truth, and the minister eventually resigned as a result of the white board incident.

This government proudly tells us that they are carrying out micro-economic reform, and they have spent $400 million on improving efficiency on the waterfront. Some may say that that is good and, in fact, efficiency improvements on the waterfront would be good. However, when they find out that as a result of the government spending this $400 million it now takes ships longer to turn around than before they commenced this process, these words seem rather hollow indeed. It raises the question: is this really as good as it gets?

The balance of trade in this country has been going backwards for some time. It was $2.9 billion in one month of this year and regularly has been around $2.5 billion per month. This is money that we do not have, but it is money that we or our children or our children's children will eventually have to pay back to the rest of the world.

This government wants to tell us that they are addressing the problems and our exports are increasing, and they quote figures to confirm this. But what they do not tell us is that the Asian region in particular has been growing rapidly and that we are not maintaining our market share as a percentage of that growth in these exports.

There are opportunities for us to produce products in this country and to value add. We do offer a secure location for companies. But why would they establish a manufacturing operation in this country when our Asian neighbours are providing five-year tax holidays or other incentives to encourage businesses to establish themselves?

Why would they come here to be hit with the sorts of taxation systems that we have at the moment? For example, the fringe benefits tax requires taxes on car parks that are difficult to understand and to work out and which require logbooks on vehicles, meals and a range of other issues. In 1995-96 the fringe benefits tax will collect $2.84 billion—a real incentive for many of these businesses to get functional in this country!

Massive taxation increases have been required over the years to fund government implemented programs. Some of them have been necessary, but many of them have been introduced for no more cynical reason than as a vote buying exercise prior to an election. This is so much so that voters have been conditioned to wait for the handouts that will be provided at election time.

In the last 35 years we have seen expenditure in infrastructure in this country fall from just under eight per cent to around four per cent. It begs the question: how many real jobs could we create if we looked again into this area of improvement and infrastructure? I am pleased to see in Victoria that Jeff Kennett is actually doing some of that work in infrastructure to create some of the real jobs that are necessary in our country. If we were able to create an environment in which the 800,000-plus small businesses in this country could see the light at the end of the tunnel and employ just one more person, we would have no unemployment problems in this country today.

Instead, we have seen this government use every method possible to camouflage the real unemployment figures. We have seen massive increases in the numbers completing tertiary education. Whilst I acknowledge the need to improve education standards to keep pace with the changes in technology, the jobs have not been there on the completion of these qualifications. These days large numbers of university graduates are working behind hotel bars or waiting on tables—not to pay their way through university as they used to, but because they cannot find a job in their chosen field with the qualifications they have.

We have a range of employment schemes in this country to get our long-term unemployed off the long-term unemployment list. Some of them will get permanent jobs. However, many of them will go back onto the unemployment list and will no longer be shown on the list as long-term unemployed.

Some people may consider my comments from time to time to be critical of the unemployed. But let me say that few people in this place have invited the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) to their electorate, as I have, to expound his schemes. Whilst I do not necessarily agree with him, if we could create jobs through those schemes to allow some of these people to be—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the grievance debate today to talk about a survey I recently concluded in my electorate and to talk about some of the results from that survey, particularly in relation to what a lot of people in Victoria think about the Kennett government. We recently completed this survey and had over 4,300 responses. A range of concerns was highlighted in those responses, particularly about the actions of the Kennett Liberal government. They were the sorts of concerns that people are facing in Victoria and have faced over the last 2 1/2 years.

PARA.TAB: The concerns cover a range of issues and I will focus on some of them today. One concern in particular was the issue of local government amalgamations, those reforms and particularly the removal of democratically elected councils and their replacements with unelected commissioners. The concerns relate to the inability to have a situation where people can contact representatives from their council to address the minor concerns, which are major to them, that relate to their local community.

The circumstances are that commissioners in general have not been able to reach the public's expectations with respect to this issue. I have been relatively lucky in my local area, particularly in the city of Greater Dandenong; but certainly the view of the community is that that is a difficulty.

The Kennett government originally planned for elections to be held in those councils in March 1996. Subsequently, they changed that to March 1997. That was criticised by a number of commissioners. In fact, recently the chief commissioner of the city of Monash cited that as one of the reasons why he was retiring from his position early. He said that he just could not possibly stay in the job for that period.

We have also heard the Premier comment on that issue again in regard to the city of Melbourne. He recently said that it could be five years before there was a democratically elected council in the city of Melbourne. This is a basic issue of democracy. It is an issue of concern to me and to many residents of Melbourne. What we are seeing is an attempt to abrogate the government's responsibility to be accountable—a situation where, on a continuing basis, unelected representatives of the people are acting on behalf of the government, often in a way which is seen to be detrimental to the needs of the local residents.

I want to raise an issue involving ethnic communities in Victoria and their situation with the state government. Ethnic communities in Victoria are many and varied. They are small and large. They come from well over 100 countries. They are often tight-knit and they are often in need of government support. People from non-English speaking backgrounds often find it more difficult to access health services and education services and also find it more difficult to compete in the employment market.

The Minister for Ethnic Affairs in the Victorian government is in fact the Premier. Over the last 2 1/2 years, in my travels around not only my electorate but most of metropolitan Melbourne, I have attended many functions of many and varied ethnic communities. I am yet to attend a function where the Minister for Ethnics Affairs from the state government has been present. There have been present on occasions a representative of the Premier, assorted backbenchers or a parliamentary secretary, but the minister himself has not appeared to be able to avail himself to those communities—that is, unless there is an issue that he sees is of some political significance.

One issue that particularly comes to mind is that which involved the Greek community and the Macedonian community some time ago. The Premier was very vocal in support of the Greek community on that issue. Without going into the detail of that issue, I say this: a government that is led by a person who seeks to be divisive and to act to support one part of the community he represents versus another on an issue which essentially is not in the bailiwick of his government is really playing with fire. That has been the way the Premier, as ethnic affairs minister, has sought to act within the Victorian government. I think it is a very sorry state of affairs and it shows something about the way he sees people should play politics in a state: by being parochial and essentially trying to turn one part of the community against another.

Another issue which has come up in recent times is freeway tolls. The state government has a proposal for a rather massive infrastructure development entitled the Citylink, which is a major freeway redevelopment in metropolitan Melbourne. I think that any resident of Melbourne would know that traffic on freeways as they stand at present and the difficulties that exist are significant, but this proposal is really a Rolls Royce proposal to deal with a problem which is not of that significance. It also ignores dealing with what could be done about improving public transport links.

I contrast that with the involvement of the federal government through the better cities program and the recent extension of the metropolitan rail line in Victoria to Cranbourne in my electorate. That was a major infrastructure development—over $30 million worth of expenditure—which has seen public transport usage in that area increase significantly.

The situation as it now stands is that the government is going to go ahead with tolls. I, just as others have, sound a warning now to the Victorian government: tolls have been found throughout Australia to be an unpopular initiative, an initiative which the public in general have been shown to be averse to. A toll such as that proposed would involve something along the lines of a $3 one-way trip. Therefore, it would cost an average family which was travelling regularly along those roads to work and so forth something like $1,500 per annum, which is a significant cost to a family. It will affect large numbers of residents of Melbourne, in both the Tullamarine corridor and my own area through the south-eastern arterial. There are alternatives for the way this could have been done. This option will effectively be very adverse to ordinary working families within the Melbourne metropolitan area.

A range of other issues have come up. Health and education are two major issues. In relation to the issue of health in Victoria, major hospital disputes have occurred, in which the Premier's role can at best be described as destructive and, at worst, deceptive. In relation to the ambulance service, there have been increasing difficulties in actually getting service. We have had a number of small but significant horror stories communicated to us in the office about what has occurred with the ambulance service.

With regard to education, class sizes are growing on a continual basis. Schools are being pitted against one another through the schools of the future program. The end result of that will be that a lot of schools which are in real need of additional resources will not get them. Schools have closed throughout the metropolitan and country areas of Victoria, and that has created additional pressure on the ability of local communities to access the services that they need for their families.

On the question of taxation and charges, there has been a very major turnaround. In the early 1990s, the Liberal Party in this chamber and also in the Victorian opposition at that stage were always railing against the question of taxation and charges. Yet, with respect to the Kennett government, we have seen a $100 deficit levy allocated to each property in the state of Victoria. There is no equity in this measure. It is $100 for a one-bedroom flat in Broadmeadows. It is also $100 for a huge mansion in Toorak. It is not about equity; it is a taxation revenue measure. It is not about equity; it is about getting money in the coffers, with no concern for the social justice implications of the measure.

A similar flat rate is charged for water and sewerage—$24 for water, $24 for sewerage. Again, it does not matter what the size of your property or your water usage is, you cop that charge straight up-front. The state government in Victoria is now, as I understand it, the highest taxing state government in the country. We hear rumours from the government about removing those charges before an election, but the fact is that they are still there and they continue to be a real drain on the coffers of ordinary working families.

The problem with the Kennett government in Victoria—and it will also be a problem if the coalition government succeeds in the federal sphere—is the question of lean government versus mean government. This current federal government has been criticised over the last few years for cutbacks in the Public Service and for the changes it has made in terms of economic restructuring, but essentially we have tried to temper that with improvements to the social security system and the overall social justice system in this country which will allow families to live in comfort.

Victoria has a mean government. It is a mean government that will not act upon the needs of the local community. It introduces charges without any concern for their impact on people. It is a government which does not care about the concerns of the average Victorian. In the federal sphere, the opposition—the government in waiting—will follow the same sorts of policies in government, as has clearly been shown by its recent comments to the media on public service reform. What has occurred in Victoria should not occur at a federal level. What has occurred in Victoria is something that should be redressed in the near future when the Kennett government gets around to calling an election.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has developed a bold plan to provide Australians with higher retirement incomes and to boost national saving and investment. Compulsory superannuation is the cornerstone of the government's strategy. Since the late 1980s, employers have contributed for their employees under awards and the superannuation guarantee. As a result, over 90 per cent of Australian employees now have superannuation, up from less than 40 per cent a decade ago.

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer (Mr Willis) announced a further boost to superannuation in the last budget. From 1997, many employees will begin making their own superannuation contributions paid from award wage rises. In addition, most workers making superannuation contributions will be able to claim a matching government payment in their tax returns. The result is that most workers will have the equivalent of 15 per cent of salary paid into superannuation by the year 2003.

The government remains firmly committed to maintaining the pension for those who need it. Our policies mean Australians will have more income in retirement through a combination of superannuation and part pension. Superannuation assets are expected to increase tenfold in the next 25 years. This brings important responsibilities for both the government and the private sector.
For its part, the government has sought to strengthen public confidence in superannuation by:

enacting the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 which clarifies the responsibilities of fund trustees and strengthens the powers of the industry regulator, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, ISC;
establishing the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal to provide redress to people in dispute with their fund;
taking steps to protect small superannuation balances being eroded by fees and charges;
embarking on a public education campaign to promote the benefits of superannuation saving for retirement.

The financial sector also has a part to play in promoting confidence in superannuation. Financial institutions and advisers must explain the benefits of long-term saving and prudent investment in a diversified portfolio. Most importantly, they must justify the government's decision to have superannuation managed in the private sector by delivering strong fund performance over the medium to longer term.

This bill makes a minor amendment to the method of calculating the `late lodgment amount' set out in the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Act 1991. The late lodgment amount can become payable where a superannuation entity is late in lodging its ISC annual return. It forms part of the supervisory levy which superannuation entities pay to cover the cost of prudential supervision of the industry.
The bill is not expected to have any overall impact on revenue. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and I commend the bill to the House.

PARA.TAB: Despite what the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) has just told us, the sad reality is that the greatest shortcoming for more than a decade in Labor's economic and social strategy has been Australia's chronic lack of national savings. This has been a major constraint on our economic growth, together with a failure to fully integrate our tax and social security systems with superannuation and savings policy.

Incidentally, economic consultant Dr Vince FitzGerald, who was used by the government for an excellent report on national savings, said some two years ago that Australia's savings had fallen to its lowest level this century, excluding the Depression and both world wars. For most of the post-war period, national savings were around 23 per cent of GDP. By 1991-92, this figure had fallen to 16 per cent and has risen very slightly since then. Consequently, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will appreciate that, while the government is on the right track in terms of the need for superannuation policy, one has to question in detail whether the overall strategy will establish the parameters for the program which they want to implement.

The week before last the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) launched a $12.5 million taxpayer-funded education program in an attempt to win widespread public support for the government's superannuation strategy. While there is general support—and the opposition accepts this—for the concept of superannuation, in principle, as a method for long-term saving, under Labor it is perfectly clear that consumer confidence in superannuation remains low. That is the reason we have this taxpayer funded program.

Last November a study conducted by the Australian Consumers Council found that 50 per cent of those surveyed believed superannuation was a poor investment. In the same month the Australian Taxation Office released the first results of its survey into superannuation. The survey found that young people between 18 and 25 believe it is too early to be involved in superannuation; that those between 25 and 45 believe they have too many other financial commitments; and that those aged between 45 and 55 believe it is too late to start saving for retirement. So it is very much a case of `not in my backyard'.

Several months later, ASSIRT investment research warned that confidence in superannuation could soon fall to crisis levels, with the results of its March 1995 survey showing a seven per cent fall in the number of people who believe that superannuation is a good investment. What were the reasons for this? Among others, respondents said that poor investment returns, lack of perceived tax benefits, the complexity of the superannuation system resulting from the numerous changes—some 2,000 that I have been able to identify—as well as tax law changes were largely to blame.

Superannuation is also perceived as being too rigid as a personal savings vehicle as it locks up savings before retirement age and is not available as security for personal borrowings. In addition, contributors are frustrated by the lack of control over their funds, feeling that their financial destiny is entirely in the hands of the government and the finance industry.

These surveys suggest that confidence will improve only if superannuation is made more simple, predictable and relevant to the medium-term and long-term needs of contributors. There is also a need to guarantee that the pension will continue to be available to those who qualify. I have put it on record on a number of occasions that the opposition is totally committed to the existing social security arrangements, and people who qualify for the pension will continue to receive it.

While the education program is obviously important—although whether it will achieve the outcome remains to be seen—it should not be seen as an excuse for failing to make the obvious reforms that consumers want. We have a sceptical community and, in that community, superannuation must be promoted honestly and without resorting to political hyperbole.
Unfortunately, we have a Prime Minister who is well known for his weakness in that particular area. His statement on the day on which he made the launch, among other things, said:

SPEECH.PARA: To give an example, someone on an average weekly earnings now—that's someone on about $32-33,000—when they retire, they will retire on a lump sum just under half a million dollars.

Such generous end benefits depend on critical assumptions not least of which are the age of contributors, the period for which they will be making those contributions, the level of contributions, whether they have been fully funded, whether they have been covered by adequate level of employment and so forth.

PARA.TAB: Of course, Mr Keating's package assumes a steady rate of CPI growth of three per cent, wages growth of four per cent and a generous fund earnings rate of seven per cent. Any variation in those factors will mean that achieving a sum total of half a million dollars as a payout, as suggested by the Prime Minister, in real rather than nominal terms, will be exceedingly difficult. But unfortunately, as I said, resorting to hyperbole, he has given us the distinct impression that anybody even in the work force today, because of the government's SGC arrangements, will qualify for such a payout. That is patently absurd and patently untrue.

In addition, according to the Treasury's own estimates, to achieve that sum a contributor would have to enter the work force in seven years time at the age of 25 when the government superannuation scheme is fully implemented, and work full time on average wages for at least 40 years beyond the year 2002. It is clear that today's workers cannot expect to have a part of, much less own, the Prime Minister's very heavily fertilised money tree, which has become the symbol of this entire program.

I find it very sad—and I am already receiving mail and complaints from constituents on this matter—that the whole tenor of the advertising program is based on statements such as `Provided you put money into the fund you will get these benefits; they are guaranteed'. Sadly, that is not true. They are not guaranteed; they are not covered by the Banking Act. Superannuation law is quite separate from the banking law, and the benefits are not guaranteed by the Commonwealth. That is a point which has to be quite clearly understood but it is obviously not the point the government wants people to know about.

The fact is that if you dissect the community in terms of winners and losers on this exercise, you do not get the response that the Prime Minister would like us to see. Many women will be unlikely to receive a benefit anywhere near the amount touted by the Prime Minister, given that their average annual income is about half that of men and many women spend longer periods out of the work force. On average, women spend just 17 years in paid employment compared with 39 years for men, although it is clear that that is now in the process of changing.

It is not just women. For example, under the compulsory superannuation scheme no worker in their late 40s who is on average weekly earnings could possibly accumulate sufficient superannuation savings to keep them when they are in retirement. Even someone aged 50 and earning $80,000 a year, which is well above the pension rate, would have to save at least 20 per cent of their salary to accumulate $490,000, in today's dollars, by age 65.

Even Accord Mark VIII—this grand, shining emblem of industrial relations progress under Labor—shows that a worker on the lowest award rate, a worker who is receiving the Accord safety net pay increases, would in the year 1998 be $8.25 a week worse off in real terms by the end of the Accord while employees not covered by awards would simply miss out.

Why is that? It is because, unlike employer contributions which are mandated in law, employee contributions under the government's arrangements are entirely in the hands of the Industrial Relations Commission and the process of the award negotiations. If those people are not under awards then the big question is whether they are covered for superannuation, and it would appear that the answer is no. Consequently, for a growing proportion of the work force, Mr Keating's grand design of a $500,000 retirement benefit is as fanciful today as Mr Hawke's promise that after 1990 no Australian child would live in poverty.

I should also make the point clearly here that, when the Treasurer (Mr Willis) spoke with me at a conference put on by ASFA last Thursday, he made the allegation that, under coalition policies, people would be considerably less well off in superannuation than they are under this proposal. I want to reiterate what was said on that day by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard); that is, no Australian worker will be `worse off' under coalition policy than they are under the current government's policy on superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they will have a job.
—And they will have a job. That means that they can pay into their superannuation and that their benefits will rise and not fall.

PARA.TAB: Let me refer to the question of industrial relations impact. No-one doubts that the SGC payments and employee superannuation contributions will have significant implications for the industrial relations system of this country. I have noted previously that low paid workers will be worse off. In an attempt to play down this apparently unforeseen effect of the Accord Mark VIII, Treasurer Willis has advanced the argument that superannuation contributions represent ordinary savings, which we all know is simply not correct. He says that these are savings that have been put aside. That is not an adequate explanation for the superannuation process.

On 20 July last his colleague, the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Johns), effectively conceded this point when he said that compulsory contributions are a reallocation between present and future earnings. Consequently, low paid workers will actually receive less in the hand as a result of the Accord. He went on to say that the 1997 review of awards by the AIRC, which is conveniently timed to be in the same year as the introduction of this process, will ensure that no employee will be out of pocket as a result of superannuation contributions. If that is true, then the only conclusion that can be drawn is that employers will be paying more. We know that is precisely the reason why the mandatory element does not cover employees; it only covers employers.

If the government compensates employees for their three per cent superannuation contributions by pay increases through the award system, surely it follows that there will be a premium for those workers who remain in the system and belong to a union. Clearly, there will be a disincentive to move to a more flexible, high wage, high productivity enterprise agreement system involving employers and employees.

Consideration should therefore be given to the status of non-unionists in regard to the selection of trustees for industry funds where it is normally the prerogative of the employer organisations, the dominant union or the ACTU. But, in many cases, union membership is a minority interest. Therefore, while trustees are by law responsible for safeguarding the interests of all contributors, there is clearly a problem here when non-unionists, often in a majority, may not be adequately included in the process of selecting who their trustees should be.

It has always been coalition policy to support superannuation payments made by both employers and employees. While employer contributions are identified in legislation, employee contributions have been left entirely in the hands of the AIRC. The question therefore is whether that is an adequate situation for a government that claims that it wants to have 90-plus per cent of the work force covered by the system. Clearly, this is a weakness which has not been addressed.

I want to refer now to some of the questions about savings strategy objectives. Clearly, our national savings strategy must have twin objectives: to reduce dependence on social security and the age pension—thus increasing public savings—and, at the same time, to encourage private savings. On that point, the government and the opposition are as one. But the attainment of these objectives must take into account their impact on the disposable income of individuals.

At the same time as Australian workers face reduced disposable incomes because of a compulsory superannuation package, if the predictions about inflationary trends are correct they will also face rises in interest rates and home mortgages while real wages will remain virtually stagnant. In fact, a mortgage rate of 10.5 per cent today has the same impact as a rate of 16 per cent had on the take-home pay of workers in the late 1980s. Clearly, that is going to increase pressure for additional credit just to maintain standards of living.

Government policy has also designated superannuation as a tax preferred investment over all other forms of saving: banks, building societies, credit unions and so forth. There is a clear danger in that. Much of the new savings which are now being compulsorily channelled into superannuation are, effectively, simply a switch between normal non-superannuation savings and superannuation savings. The latter are expected to increase to $2,408.5 billion dollars or 64 per cent of GDP by the year 2030 while, at the same time—and clearly as a result of that—bank and NBFI deposits are expected to fall. This will obviously have quite serious economic and social consequences, not to mention the realities of the problem of having a tilted playing field for investments on the one side and for drawing on savings on the other.
I have made the following point in a discussion paper I gave to LIFA, in which I said:

SPEECH.PARA: The future direction of superannuation and national savings strategy must take into account the significant lifestyle changes occurring in our society . . . Given the changing social paradigm the consumer will expect a long-term savings strategy to include opportunities for medium term savings.

This is in line with recommendations of Dr FitzGerald in his report on national savings released in June 1993. Regrettably, the government has done nothing at all to address this question of intermediate savings strategy.

PARA.TAB: Consequently, ACOSS and consumer organisations have rightly criticised the government's savings policy because they claim that it will significantly reduce the take-home pay of low income earners. The government's response is to say, `Nonsense! We are starting by having a one per cent compulsory employee contribution rate which will work up to three per cent.' What they are not saying, of course, is that the hidden agenda is that ultimately the employer will have to pay the lot. That is the hidden agenda which the government does not want to talk to us about.

In the meantime, however, there is a real risk that the level of income of low income workers is going to actually fall at a time when many of them need it most: the family formation period when they are paying off mortgages and so forth. It would be far more equitable if low and medium income earners were offered access to a flexible intermediate savings vehicle which would have some tax advantages linked to savings periods of, say, five to 10 years. That would give them the ability to save when they were able to save and, at the same time, to have access to at least part of those savings to meet those crisis issues of life which we all have to face. That ability is totally locked in, in a situation where all your available savings are forced into a long-term savings arrangement such as superannuation is.

An inevitable outcome of the government's policy of introducing the three per cent compulsory employee contribution from 1997, together with the government co-payment of up to $1,000—and I must emphasise that that is totally unfunded and that we have now been told by the Treasurer that there will be no legislation for it before the next election, so that we are once again in the interesting situation we were in before the last—

TALK.START.PARA: —No l-a-w law?
—Yes. We had the l-a-w tax cuts which never happened. Now we are going to have the non l-a-w superannuation arrangements—
—They were l-i-e-s!

—Which also may not happen. Are we seriously going to believe this government is able to deliver on what is clearly a totally unfunded commitment? To date, five or six per cent of employer contributions have been left largely in the hands of industry fund trustees to invest through fund managers, and employees have felt divorced from the decision making process, which they tend to see as being the responsibility of the employer.

PARA.TAB: But after 1997 employees will become well aware of their reduced take-home pay and, as a result, there will undoubtedly be an increased interest in the investment outcome of individual funds. Any adverse performance, such as we have seen in recent times, will no doubt bring with it a considerable consumer backlash, especially as we are talking about a compulsory system. The future for fund managers in that environment will be further complicated by the fact that by the year 2002 the federal government will have contributed at least $4.5 billion, according to the last budget, directly into superannuation. I am aware of no other area of fiscal responsibility where the government has ever injected so much taxpayer money back into the system as a means of supplementing savings.

This means that by the next decade the level of direct government support to superannuation will be in the vicinity of $10 billion annually. How does that place it in relation to other major areas of expenditure? It is significant. For defence, $10.8 billion is projected for the 1998-99 financial year, and for education, $11.9 billion is projected over the same period. In other words, for the first time ever you are going to have this vast quantum, some $10 billion, going into superannuation, thereby competing in the public's mind with some of the very major areas of government expenditure.

By any yardstick that commitment is substantial, and it is going to loom as a very large target. Over 40 years it will cost in excess of $400 billion, but by the year 2035, according to the retirement income modelling task force, employer SGC and co-contributions will still only reduce pension outlays by 0.3 to 0.4 per cent of gross domestic product—about $1.7 billion in real terms. And for that we are paying out $10 billion a year. That is the actuarial calculation which I urge the government to consider very seriously indeed: the cost-benefit relationship.

So what will be the political impact? I think it is going to come in two directions. Firstly, there will be a growing number of parliamentarians who will start questioning whether the rate of return is justified. They will undoubtedly voice the concerns of their electorate. Secondly, the argument that the government should set rules for investment may become even more shrill. Almost every time you have a debate on superannuation in this chamber, members of the government stand up and say that superannuation money should be directed into national projects, into infrastructure investment, et cetera. The Treasurer then rushes around telling everybody, `No, no, it is not true. We are not going to interfere. It is entirely in the hands of the trustees and the fund managers. It is not the role of government.' The point I am making is that, as this quantum of money grows, the political imperative for governments to interfere in the process is obviously going to grow, and the evidence is quite clearly there in Hansard.

I believe that these twin pressures will make asset management even more hazardous than it is at present. We see that the portfolio theory for asset allocation takes account of historical trends in investment. However, increased political interest in the outcomes could well minimise the ability of managers to take the correct technical decisions. And we have seen how often that has happened in the past in other areas of government interference. Performance in the various categories for investment has varied historically. During the 1950s and the 1960s, we saw a decade and more which appeared to be an unending growth cycle. This may well happen again in the next decade. I do not know, you do not know; none of us does. But there is an equal risk that in the same period we may actually see an underperformance in economic terms or certainly in fiscal management terms.

As the market for investment becomes more internationalised—and we now see vast sums of money passing hither and thither on a 24-hour basis—the attraction for Australian fund managers to look offshore for investment potential is obviously going to grow. After all, we are talking about two trillion dollars in the system—a vast amount of money. The question which has to be asked is: is the Australian economy going to be sufficiently broad and flexible enough to be able to absorb a large component of that money, or will the money have to go offshore as a means of guaranteeing the best possible return?

That is one of the reasons why the opposition believes that a more sophisticated and detailed policy of privatisation is significant in this particular area. To take one example, if Telstra were sold completely, it could realise between $20 billion and $30 billion, but still retain a majority Australian ownership. Under a coalition government there would not be a shambles like we have had with Qantas.

The arrangement was that the majority of the funds were to remain Australian yet, a month or so after the closure of the initial allocation of shares, nobody seems to know who owns what. However, there is a very strong fear that government policy has been breached and that a majority of Qantas shares may be now owned by foreigners.

Therefore, while we in the coalition are committed to a policy of privatisation, we believe that that is going to open up for fund managers a new range of potential investment opportunities which are clearly not available to the Australian market at this stage.

There is unanimous agreement between both parties on the question of the need for increased domestic savings in Australia as an essential component for economic growth. A quantum jump in our standard of living cannot be achieved unless foreign debt is drastically eased through, among other things, a major increase in net domestic savings. The household savings ratio in Australia is the lowest ever recorded. That is the result of Labor's policies.

Consequently, the recent evidence that household debt levels have increased from 45 per cent to 65 per cent of disposable income over the last decade is clearly a matter of considerable seriousness. Increased domestic debt can only be justified provided the equity value in home prices continues to rise side by side with standards of living. But what do we see? The reality is that home equity values are actually falling and our standard of living is clearly stagnating.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's lower than Singapore's.

—This is compelling evidence that increased superannuation savings and productive investment, at least to date, have had very little impact on economic recovery—which was built on the wrong fundamentals. On the question of Singapore, which was just mentioned by the member for Maranoa, people speak in the highest terms about the Singapore model. In 20 years it has changed from a country with a relatively small economy into one of the tigers of South-East Asia and it now has an effective superannuation savings system of up to 40 per cent of household income.

PARA.TAB: In contrast, Australia has not succeeded in designing a methodology for financing growth, especially for small and medium enterprises. This sector will produce most job growth and it will also provide the entrepreneurial enterprise from which innovations should ultimately emerge. A case in point is the company Netscape in the United States. It is a small company that in 16 months grew in assets from $4.1 million to between $3 billion and $4 billion, all on the strength of its software innovations and access to the Internet. While the size and depth of the United States market is clearly different to Australia's, nevertheless we must do much better to encourage innovation and to turn innovative ideas into marketable opportunities.

Access to credit at a price that employers can afford is fundamental to our economic health. That is the one thing that this government has ultimately failed to do. Unless we can successfully build our economy using more of our own capital for import replacement and export industries, it is obvious that present government policy will simply be a recipe for much higher unemployment at the next cyclical downturn, which all members know will come as sure as day follows night in the progression of life.

Therefore, building up those SMEs which I referred to is essential at this time. We have opportunities in our own region, especially for high-tech developments in Asia, but these opportunities will only remain open while we have technological and comparative cost advantages, and access to finance is absolutely critical. It is probably going to take 10 years to get those companies up and running, but one of the issues which has to be raised is what the role of superannuation savings will be—which, as I said, are long-term savings, which, by definition, are ideal for that type of investment. It is necessary to make sure that fund managers are encouraged to put aside at least part of their funding to ensure that good ideas and young Australian companies in the developmental stages get the opportunities which they clearly need.

If Australia is to enter into a developmental phase of sustained growth which has more substance than that just suggested by Mr Keating's five minutes of economic sunshine, it is obvious that we have to reduce significantly our exposure to overseas debt and further imbalances in our current account. We will need to see higher real growth rates on investments but that is not going to be easy in a low inflationary environment.

Nevertheless, superannuation funds, by their very nature, are long term. They are attractive sources for longer term infrastructure funding. They also provide an opportunity for a matching of long-term assets with liabilities but, regrettably, that is another thing which has not been effectively one of our strengths for much of the last decade.

So, while we are opening up new avenues for infrastructure financing, we want to be able to give our fund managers the opportunities to be able to look into those sources as an alternative to having to go overseas. If our capital has to migrate overseas in the quantities which have been suggested—as high as 40 per cent of the total quantum of funds available—then that is a clear demonstration of the failure of this Labor government to be able to have an investment policy which has been able to generate the growth and which, in turn, creates the opportunities for further investment in the Australian economy.

Australians do not mind compulsory saving providing they can see some results for it, providing they can see jobs for their children, providing they can see economic growth and providing they can see a future for the citizens of this great country. If, at the end of the day, 40 per cent of that money has to go overseas, as has been suggested by various fund managers recently, it demonstrates the total bankruptcy of Labor's policy over the last 13 years.

Putting that into context, not only were the wage plug people who pay their taxes in my electorate excluded from superannuation before 1983 under the management of the coalition but their taxes also subsidised the tax concessions of the high-income, wealthy males who had the benefits of superannuation. It is appalling. Why do I sit on this side of this chamber? Why is my commitment to the purposes of the Labor Party and the labour movement? Because I have experienced all of those things over my lifetime. I have seen them; I know of them.

There was a guarantee by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in his reply to the last budget that existing retirement benefits would be maintained and retained if a coalition government came to office. He said that existing retirement benefits would be retained. He did not give a commitment that the coalition, in government, would continue with the program that we have undertaken to put into place that ensures continuing, accumulating benefits for wage and salary earners in Australia.

My experience leads me to believe that that means existing benefits would be maintained—but frozen. If they are frozen, as I believe they will be if the coalition comes into government—there is no question in my mind about that—by the time a 25-year-old now on average weekly earnings in today's dollar terms retires, the superannuation guarantee at present levels will have cost him or her between $230,000 and $260,000 in accumulated superannuation benefit. I question whether those 25-year-olds going into the work force on average weekly earnings would be prepared to take that risk. Within a relatively short period of time, they are going to be asked to make that judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.

—The member for Wentworth interjects that one of the points I just made is not true. I do not know that it is not true. I referred to the fact that the Leader of the Opposition said in his budget reply that the coalition government would preserve existing retirement benefits. I said I thought that that means they would be frozen. If there is any doubt about that, as the interjection suggests there is, let me tell you something that is true—as true as I stand here.

PARA.TAB: When the present Leader of the Opposition became Treasurer to Malcolm Fraser, one of the first steps he took was to abandon the indexation of age pensions that we had put into place. I know that the person who interjected is a man of goodwill. I do not believe that he wants to see any penalties visited upon people in their retirement. If that is true—and he is shaking his head in confirmation—he should be with me over here. I invite him, and I would welcome him. It may well be that in the fullness of time, as we have an opportunity to see how these things work out, he may well choose to do so.

There are two essential elements in our approach to superannuation. The first element is retirement security. The government has also emphasised—as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker—that, in connection with retirement security, there are three essential components for us. We have guaranteed to maintain the age pension. That is the basic safety net. No-one, as far as we are concerned, falls through that. In addition to that, we have the compulsory savings element, which now consists of the superannuation guarantee and the minimum employee contribution. As well as that, we have the voluntary element of superannuation, which is encouraged by substantial tax concessions—still provided by government—and the government's matching payments.

Those three components, as far as we are concerned, are the three pillars of our commitment to retirement benefits and to the security of Australian men and women when they reach retirement age. I want to see a bipartisan approach and a commitment from the opposition that they will endorse that approach and that they will not just freeze existing benefits if—if, if, if!—they come into government, but will continue our plan, our program and our strategy to ensure that the benefits for Australians in retirement will continue to grow.

Let me make this point as clearly and as forcefully as I can. The Australian community—whatever their reservations from time to time about the Labor Party and about the labour movement and about Labor governments, governments to which I am absolutely committed—know that what I say is true. If they are seeking from any political movement in Australia and from any government a firm, positive, honest commitment to security in their retirement, they will look to this government, to this party and to this movement and they will look nowhere else. They know that as well as I do.

The second element in our approach to superannuation is national savings, and reference has been made to the fact that Dr Vince FitzGerald, in his report in 1993, referred to the positive deficiency in the level of savings in Australia. Yes, there is a deficiency, and that deficiency in savings is critical in relation to financing the type of investment that we need to be undertaking in Australia. It is also critical to the current account deficit because, if people are not saving, they are buying; and, if they are buying, they are very often buying goods from overseas and that, of course, contributes towards the current account deficit. So we need to build national savings.

What better way to do it than to build in the process of encouraging, assisting and enabling people to provide for their own retirement? Not only that, but we have said to them, `With those employee contributions that are being made, the government will match every dollar you put in.' As a result of that, by early in the next century, the equivalent of 15 per cent of people's income will be going in to provide for their retirement. Some people say it is nine per cent from employers, but that is not correct: six per cent will come from employers, another six per cent will come from employees, and the balance of three per cent will come from the government's matching commitment, making a total of 15 per cent.

I said that some people had claimed that the employers would be contributing nine per cent, but they will be doing nothing of the kind. The first three per cent that came into existence in 1985 was a trade-off. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will remember that this government said to the ACTU and to the trade union movement, `As a result of productivity gains, employees—wage and salary earners—in Australia are entitled to a three per cent increase in their wages and salaries. Do you want that in your pocket to take home, or do you want us to arrange to put that three per cent into superannuation for you?' To their credit, the ACTU and the trade union movement said, `Put it into super.'

The opposition and employers now claim that was the employers' three per cent. No, it was not. It has been suggested that with the progressive increase there will be a contribution from employers equal to six per cent. That will then match the six per cent from employees and the three per cent matching from government. To a very large extent, that is going to assist to overcome that deficiency in savings as a result of that. In fact, it is estimated that by the turn of the century it will have increased savings by two per cent of GDP. That will mean that, by the year 2006, each year savings will be three per cent of GDP greater than they would otherwise have been. By the year 2021 that will be four per cent of GDP. I think our GDP is about $450 billion. Translated into today's dollars, that means that we will have increased national savings by the year 2021 by an amount of $18 billion.

There are a lot of things I would like to say. This is a fascinating area. The thing that I want to emphasise is that what this government has done has been to integrate its approach to retirement income, to superannuation, with the whole question of national savings, the impact that that has on the capacity of this nation to invest and the effect that it has as well on the current account deficit. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill amends the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Act 1991, the principal act, to make a minor amendment to the method of calculation of the late lodgment amount. A late lodgment amount can become payable under the principal act if a superannuation entity is late in lodging an annual return. The amendments to subsection 6(2) of the levy act will mean that a late lodgment amount will now arise for each calendar month which begins after the required return lodgment day and before the day on which the return is actually lodged. The late lodgment amount forms a component of the superannuation supervisory levy which all superannuation entities are required to pay to cover the cost of the prudential supervision of the industry.

PARA.TAB: These amendments will ensure consistency with the method of calculating the late payment penalty under subsection 15DC(2) of the Superannuation Entities Taxation Act 1987. That subsection, incidentally, is proposed to be amended by the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) of 1995, which is due to be debated some time in the not too distant future. This amendment only applies in relation to returns lodged for the 1994-95 year of income or a later year of income. The changes are not, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) has explained, expected to have any overall impact on the revenue.

The bill is essentially a housekeeping bill and it was introduced into the House on 28 June. This bill, although rather thin in terms of pages, does provide us with an opportunity to discuss matters relating to the mismanagement of superannuation policy under this government. I stated in speaking on one of the seemingly interminable bills in relation to superannuation earlier this year that a genuine retirement income strategy requires a stable and predictable environment, security, incentives to encourage financial independence, better integration of the tax and social security systems and the guarantee of a government safety net. Of these, Labor has most notably and totally failed to provide so far for a stable and predictable environment.

A survey undertaken by Brian Sweeney and Associates earlier this year on behalf of the government tried to ascertain the level of support and understanding of the superannuation system. The result was not good for the government. Almost half of those surveyed had only slight or no understanding of superannuation. This was particularly the case amongst women, students and the unemployed. The proportion with a reasonable understanding had also fallen from just over 60 per cent to just over 50 per cent since the last survey was conducted in 1992. So they are going backwards. Most misunderstandings resulted from the constant changes to the rules in government policies, the language used, taxation issues and how superannuation worked as a system for retirement income. Interestingly, 40 per cent thought they were getting poor returns for their money and over 70 per cent of respondents wanted more control over how super funds invested their money.
Ms Anne Lampe, in the Sydney Morning Herald of 5 August, made some interesting observations on the superannuation system. She wrote:

The trouble with superannuation is that it is a moving feast that is almost impossible to get a grip on because it is changing too quickly. There have been hundreds of significant and smaller changes to the super landscape since 1983 when the 15 per cent lump sum tax was first introduced, followed by further taxes on investment, reduction of tax concessions and four or five changes to maximum benefit limits. The only way people are going to understand how the super system works is for the Government—

SPEECH.PARA: and the Opposition, for that matter—to leave it alone for a while and let the rules sink in.
She went on to write:

PARA.TAB: The system is so complex that two weeks ago the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO) produced a 200-page guide designed to explain superannuation to fund trustees and community workers, and has been rushed with requests for copies at $75 apiece.

SPEECH.PARA: Ms Lampe concluded:

PARA.TAB: If the Government left the current super framework alone there would be no need to spend $12 million to explain it. If stability is not achieved in the super field the $12 million is as good as poured down the drain.

SPEECH.PARA: That is it in a comparative nutshell. How correct are her observations. But the real reason for Labor's super sell at the moment is the coming election. There should be no doubt about that. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is desperate to sell his superannuation initiative. He has been constantly talking up the impact of the superannuation changes on the supposed average worker, who earns $33,000 per annum and will receive a pay-out of $462,000. What goes unsaid in this exercise is that the example so fondly given by the Prime Minister only applies to someone who is 18 years of age today, begins full-time employment in the year 2002 and retires in 2042. George Megalogenis wrote in the Australian on 12 August:

PARA.TAB: This is not necessarily a bad message for the Government to be selling to voters.
But it doesn't sit well with Keating's promise, repeated again this week, of a $462,000 SGC bonanza for a worker on average earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on:

PARA.TAB: The job for Keating is to sell the benefits of the policy without falling into the hyperbole that tends to dog him when he talks on economic policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister is deliberately setting the scene to dupe those who are currently in the work force about their future retirement income. He is fully aware that the average voter is not familiar with the fine print of his half a million dollars SGC example. Even worse, he does not care if the population are sold a dummy, so long as they vote for his party at the next election. The Prime Minister is yet again positioning himself as the great deceiver of the true believers.

PARA.TAB: Treasury figures present a very different image from the gloss presented by our increasingly desperate Prime Minister. These figures show that the first baby boomers who retire under the SGC will still be poor enough to receive the age pension at retirement age—unless, of course, they buy additional superannuation. In the same terms, those who retire in the next 20 or 30 years will still have to rely on a pension, if only a part pension. The fact remains that even for the average person entering the labour market in 2002 superannuation will not deliver the promised retirement incomes. Take the simple fact that 70 per cent of workers earn less than the $33,000 average income per annum. They are therefore not going to receive the almost half a million dollars figure being touted by the Prime Minister.

Dr Vince FitzGerald has also been critical of the Prime Minister's focus on the $462,000 figure. The Prime Minister's assumption also neglects some realities inherent in our labour markets. Australia's work patterns are constantly changing. Workers do not stay in the same job their entire lives, nor do they necessarily stay in the same industries. Many—too many, some would say—suffer periods of redundancy and unemployment. In fact, something like eight per cent of the work force is currently unemployed.

The days of starting a job with John Smith and Co. Ltd and working there until you retire are long gone. The Prime Minister's example is a throwback to the work patterns of 30 years ago, or even the age of the FJ Holden. He is living in the past. It explains why the government has been unable to adequately resolve the problems associated with portability. Women, on the whole, will not benefit from compulsory superannuation charges to the same extent as men. Women continue to have broken work patterns due to their taking time out of the work force to bear and to raise children. They are also more concentrated in part-time, casual and temporary work. Treasury has estimated that a woman with a broken work pattern, or someone on less than average wages, could receive as little as $50,000 in retirement from the superannuation guarantee charge system.That is a long way short of the Prime Minister's half a million dollars boast.

That is not the only example of the government's exaggeration of the benefits of superannuation, as it now is. The Prime Minister has been travelling around the nation, telling all who will listen that the SGC will eventually result in an accumulation of $2 trillion in superannuation funds—up from $40 billion a decade ago and $180 billion this year. Dr FitzGerald had this to say about that:

SPEECH.PARA: The government is always prone to hype which is unfortunate—like this $2 trillion stupidity, which makes what are substantial changes sound astronomical, when substantial is good enough.

Dr FitzGerald pointed out that this growth does not look so brilliant after accounting for inflation and the growth of national income. This reduces the increase to approximately twofold. Handsome enough in itself; the Prime Minister does not need to exaggerate.

PARA.TAB: Quite simply, things are not as great as the government would have us believe. In light of the survey findings I referred to earlier, it is perhaps not surprising that the government is now going to spend $12.5 million on an advertising campaign to educate Australians on how the system works. This campaign is, however, a complete waste of taxpayers' money. The superannuation system has several major problems which need to be fixed before any major campaign begins. Unfortunately, that campaign has already begun.

Issues which need to be resolved beforehand involve portability, choice, competition, and taxes, fees and charges. I acknowledge that the industry has adopted a voluntary protocol covering portability. This has apparently reduced the amount of paperwork involved in rolling over super accounts, yet it has not resolved the issue of severe penalties applying when funds are rolled over.

I have been approached by public servants who are currently working for the Water Authority of Western Australia but are now moving outside the public sector into the employ of companies winning what are quaintly described as outsourcing contracts. These public servants want to roll over their superannuation to their own funds, yet they will be penalised 1.75 per cent for every year before the age of 55. A 30-year-old will therefore be penalised with the loss of 44 per cent of his or her accumulated superannuation. That is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's robbery.

—It is robbery. It is a disgrace. Portability without prohibitive costs should be available to all people who need to—and, indeed, are virtually required to under the law—roll over superannuation. We have a ridiculous situation where many superannuation accounts are currently incurring taxes and charges in excess of earnings. I am sure we all have had examples of that coming into our offices. There is the superannuation contribution tax, the statutorily required charges, plus administrative costs. With all the taxes and charges being levied on super accounts, it is little wonder that people are becoming disillusioned in superannuation.

PARA.TAB: It is ironic that the government taxes superannuation contributions at 15 per cent—off the top—yet is going to match employee contributions, at some time in the future, by up to three per cent. We heard the Treasurer saying that it really does not matter that we tax government employees, that we impose the fringe benefits tax on them, because it is really robbing Paul to pay Paul. Here we have it. But there is still a little bit of a margin in it, because the government is creaming off 15 per cent and is going to give three per cent of that back at some time in the distant future—perhaps.

TALK.START.PARA: —Their masters.
