—I am pleased to be able to contribute to the debate on the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1995, which was outlined by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) in the second reading speech. This bill makes a number of minor amendments to the method of calculation of the late lodgment amount.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that we will have a wide-ranging debate on this particular subject, given the great interest in superannuation that is demonstrated very positively by members on this side of the House but, unfortunately, not so positively by those opposite. As a government, we can be very proud of our record on superannuation.

The bill before us addresses a number of issues. The late lodgment amount is only one component of the superannuation supervisory levy that superannuants are required to pay to cover the cost of prudential supervision of the industry. That is important because supervision of the industry is important.

The late lodgment amount becomes payable only if a superannuant lodges a late return. Quite honestly, late lodgment should not happen, but when it does there needs to be an appropriate penalty. There must be a disincentive; people must respect the need to lodge their superannuation payments promptly. How those payments are actually made is something I have raised from time to time and something my constituents have raised with me.

I would like to digress a bit and respond to some members opposite by talking about the record of this government on superannuation. Since coming to office in 1983, this Labor government has radically transformed retirement savings through the creation of comprehensive national superannuation schemes. In the long term, that will increase retirement incomes and national savings. Clearly, if you provide for your own retirement through superannuation, it will improve your lifestyle.

I always wonder why the opposition has continually tried to attack the government's belief in the need for superannuation. Superannuation had been lacking in this country for many years, and our superannuation record is something that this government can be proud of. The opposition, instead of trying to undermine the benefits of superannuation, should be making some constructive contribution to the debate, but I have yet to see that from any opposition member.

The opposition talks about their policies in this area, but do they have any policies? This area is yet another vacuum when it comes to opposition policies. Superannuation is probably one of the most important things needed when people are preparing for their retirement. We need to ensure that people actually are looked after in their retirement and that we can provide those things.

Prior to 1983, when those opposite were in government, superannuation was the preserve of managers, some public sector workers and some white-collar workers in the private sector. I always wondered why it was never extended to the rest of the work force—obviously, there were real motives for that. The vast majority of Australian workers did not have access to superannuation to supplement their retirement incomes. This government, in pursuit of a fair and equitable retirement income policy for all Australians, has to a large extent remedied that situation through a number of key policy initiatives. It is important to have key policy initiatives. Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), can think about that.

The 1985 accord with the ACTU played a pivotal role in the superannuation process, with a universal three per cent employer provided superannuation benefit in lieu of an equivalent productivity based general wage rise. We need to remind people that the workers themselves contributed that three per cent in 1985. The award based superannuation system, which emanated from the subsequent national wage case in 1986, saw access to superannuation extended from a base of 39 per cent of employees in 1983 to 72 per cent by July 1991. That is a tremendous record.

It is really quite disgraceful that those opposite criticise the trade union movement in relation to superannuation because, without the support and cooperation of the trade union movement, we would not have the superannuation system for the Australian work force that we have today. The trade union movement is extremely important and its contribution should be acknowledged today—not only by those on this side of the House but also by those opposite. Without that cooperation and without the spirit and interest of the working men and women of this nation, we would not have achieved the superannuation goals that we have so far.

Instead of criticising the trade union movement, once again the opposition would be better off looking very supportively at the role that it has played. We need only to have seen the member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and Jennie George on TV last night to realise the attitude that those people opposite have got towards the trade union movement. Jennie George had no trouble at all running rings around Peter Reith in that debate last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on! So we do have a policy?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The member for Gippsland is not being called on to contribute.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say you had a policy.
—You started off by saying that we don't have a policy.
—The member for Gippsland will restrain himself.
—The member for Gippsland knows full well that the opposition has no policies.
—Hang on! I thought we didn't.
—For a moment, he thought they had a policy.
—No, you are all confused.
—The member for Gippsland is defying the chair and he will force me to take action. The member for Oxley has the call.

—When it comes to the trade union movement, I suppose the opposition has one policy—to be in complete opposition with the trade union movement no matter what they do instead of being a little cooperative with them. Getting back to the main subject of superannuation: to supplement the development of award superannuation, the government in the 1991 budget introduced the superannuation guarantee to further extend the coverage of superannuation for employees and to ensure compliance amongst employers in meeting their superannuation obligations to their employees. That is extremely important as well.

PARA.TAB: The combination of award superannuation and the superannuation guarantee had increased coverage to more than 90 per cent of the Australian work force as of August 1995. Once again, that is another tremendous record that Australians can be proud of. By the year 2002, under the superannuation guarantee schedule of rates, workers will receive employer superannuation support equivalent to nine per cent of their salary.

I remind honourable members opposite that when they last held office at the federal level, only 39 per cent of the work force was covered by superannuation. Now we are talking about taking that figure up to 90 per cent. I think you will all agree that this is a damning indictment of the opposition's retirement income policy at that time. They did have a policy at that time, albeit a very bad one. But, clearly, it did not require the powers of Nostradamus to see the potential of superannuation in the future direction of retirement income policy in Australia. It needed to be addressed a long time ago.

The federal government's hard work in the area of superannuation has ensured that a whole new generation of Australians has access to a superannuation base which will go a long way to ensuring financial independence when they enter retirement. That financial independence is important for a good retirement income policy. However, ensuring access to superannuation is only half the issue. The government has also legislated to ensure that superannuation funds, in which workers have invested their hard earned money, are investing their funds in a prudentially sound manner. Of course, that comes to the safety aspect of superannuation funds and that is important as well as far as the employees are concerned.

To this end, a host of legislation, including the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Act 1991, the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act, has been enacted to provide a sound regulatory framework for the operation of the superannuation industry into the 21st century. A very progressive approach!

In this contest, the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1995, which is before the House today, will play its role in ensuring the prudential supervision superannuation of the superannuation industry remains sound. The minor amendments to the calculation of the late lodgment amount which are outlined in the bill are designed to ensure the superannuation entities lodge their annual returns under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, thus allowing costs associated with the prudential supervision of the industry.

Of course, the provisions put in place by the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 allow for the prudent management of certain superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts and for their supervision by the Insurance Superannuation Commission. The regulation of the superannuation industry under the Commonwealth's powers with respect to corporations or pensions ensures public confidence in the superannuation industry and has secured increased protection of superannuation savings. We need to remind people here today of that very aspect of the protection that superannuation savings actually provide, instead of the doom and gloom that those opposite often try to put forward to undermine the importance of superannuation savings.

The enforcement powers that we legislated for in 1993 have ensured that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission can enforce the prudential requirements and obligations placed on funds and trustees under the act. I think most people would agree that the legislation has proved both efficient and effective in practice. The government's initiatives in the 1995 budget, as outlined in the budget paper `Saving for our future', build upon the sound retirement incomes policies we have in place and provide us with a comprehensive national savings plan for the future.

In the 1995-96 budget two specific initiatives were announced in terms of the superannuation component of the government's retirement incomes policy. From 1997, variations to awards will see the introduction of employee contributions to superannuation paid out of future wage rises. Contributions amounting to three per cent of average weekly ordinary time earnings will be phased in over three years. This phasing-in period will reduce undue pressure on wages and costs and should see no discernible reduction in disposable income.

To complement the three per cent phased employer superannuation contributions, the government will match dollar for dollar employee contributions with direct payments to workers' superannuation accounts by paying the second round of the One Nation tax cuts in this form. The matching payments will be capped at three per cent of the average weekly ordinary time earnings and a means test will gradually withdraw support up to a salary in a range of up to $65,000 per annum.

By the year 2000, it is estimated that the government will be paying around $4.5 billion per year into the superannuation accounts of workers. This matching government contribution is specifically targeted at low and middle income earners who have traditionally included a significant proportion of women. Indeed, prior to 1983, only 24 per cent of workers covered by superannuation were women. Government policies have seen that figure continue to rise dramatically to a point where 85 per cent are now covered by superannuation—still short, of course, of the national average.

The means testing of individual income instead of family income in terms of the government's superannuation contribution will provide many working women with a further incentive to save in their own right. This initiative builds upon previous government policy initiatives to extend superannuation coverage to women, which have included superannuation contributions being fully vested and preserved so the accumulated benefits will not be lost if a woman leaves her job for any reason; the relaxation of occupational linkage requirements, which allows women and men to pay superannuation contributions up to two years after stopping work or seven years where they are on leave for the purpose of raising a family; and a reduction in the number of hours which must be worked in any week from 20 to 10 hours before workers are eligible to contribute to superannuation. They are all very positive steps in recognising the role that women play in our society.

As pointed out by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) last week in an address to the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia, the government's matching contributions will ensure significantly higher incomes in retirement for ordinary workers—the bulk of the workers in this nation. Indeed, during the first few decades of the next century, the majority of workers—that is, those with incomes below average weekly earnings—will progressively move to a situation where their retirement income will be no less than their pre-retirement income when the age pension is combined with the income stream derived from superannuation benefits.

As the Treasurer rightly points out, this represents a dramatic change in after retirement living standards for many wage earners who would have previously had only the age pension in retirement. Once again, in preparing for retirement and in having a decent incomes retirement policy, a lot of these things will improve people's retirement incomes and hence their quality of life.

The government's emphasis upon superannuation as a retirement income policy for the future is of course predicated upon the age pension supplementary superannuation payments in retirement. The government, unlike the opposition, is committed to maintaining the age pension at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, buttressed by associated social security arrangements to ensure an adequate income safety net in retirement. Once again, that safety net is a feature of this government's social justice attitudes, and the same thing happens in the industrial relations area.

The opposition over past decades has failed to match Labor's commitment to ensuring that the age pension remains a viable income retirement supplement. Unfortunately, a vacuum at the headland of opposition policy gives us very little insight into the future direction of tory income retirement policy—or any other policy for that matter.

However, given the honourable member for Bennelong's decision to cease indexation of age pensions in a former life as Treasurer of a now widely discredited government, the direction of tory policy in the context of retirement income policy would seem quite clear. That is right. It is `Back to the future' time once again.

In terms of superannuation policy, it would seem that the opposition is still wedded to its pre-1993 election policy, which is designed to return to a situation where superannuation will once again become the preserve of the rich—and perhaps even senior public servants as well. The opposition's reliance upon tax concessions to encourage people to provide for their own retirement has not worked in the past in Australia, or anywhere else in the world. It is a lesson they should have learned many years ago. Obviously, they are slow learners.

The opposition's New Right industrial relations agenda, which would see award conditions cut to a bare minimum, would certainly see the end of an award based superannuation system. That would destroy superannuation and all the work that has been done over recent years to providing a decent incomes policy for the people of Australia. Employers, always eager to reduce costs and increase profits, will no doubt take advantage of deregulated labour market conditions proposed by those opposite to stop paying superannuation contributions on behalf of their employees. That would ensure the obstruction of all the work that has been done in superannuation under this government.

Indeed, Mr Howard's agenda in terms of dismantling award based superannuation is well known. His statements about changing superannuation rules to ensure union officials do not control trust funds shows how out of touch he is with reality. Superannuation funds based upon occupations have a representative board made up of equal numbers of employer and employee representatives by law. Quite often we hear those opposite put all these furphies around that the unions have control of these superannuation funds. That representative board represents the members' interests in those particular superannuation funds.

As the Treasurer has already said in this matter, it is a sad comment on the alternative leader of this country that he has an ideological problem with workers having a say in how their own money is actually invested. The apparent determination of the opposition to return Australia to a pre-1983 superannuation system does not seem to recognise the benefits we as a nation can derive from increased savings through superannuation in the long term. Those increased savings, of course, are essential.

Australia, being such a vast country with a relatively small population, has long suffered the problem of a low savings base. The economic implications of this have been profound. With a low savings base, we have had to borrow investment capital from overseas, which in turn has been reflected in the balance of payments and current account deficit figures. In this context, it is imperative that we build our own national savings pool from which the private sector can source investment capital which will drive economic growth in the long term. As pointed out in the FitzGerald report, superannuation will play a vital role in increasing Australia's national savings base.

The government has since 1983 pursued a coordinated strategy on national savings which is built upon the increased retirement savings base already in place. Indeed, by the year 2020, the government's superannuation plan will add $18 billion each year to national savings. In this context, employees will be saving 15 per cent of their salaries through superannuation contributions, which results in higher retirement incomes in the long term.

The contribution Australian workers will be making through superannuation, through national savings, is something this country needs. We need a sound superannuation policy in this country. We have got that, but we all need to work together. (Time expired)

I detect a subtle change in that debate. The new sound is perhaps that of a fresh whipping boy being discovered by this government and its miserable fellow travellers in the media. The new villain, I am sad to announce, is the fund manager and, more particularly, the superannuation fund manager, who carries that frightful label, so redolent of Kelty and Keating venom, `the conservative superannuation fund manager'.

Their train of prosecutorial logic goes something like this: in Australia we suffer high unemployment and we suffer a chronic balance of payments deficit, so if we raise our savings rate we will, first, be able to fund more investment from domestic sources of capital and reduce our foreign debt and, second, presumably be able to supply more venture or developmental capital to small enterprises or to infrastructure projects in Australia which will in turn create more jobs and, of course, increase exports.

They say, according to this, that a large and unwieldy scheme to raise our national savings through superannuation—ignoring, of course, the potential of non-superannuation savings—will solve our problems entirely. This neat little equation begets what I think is a ridiculous notion: that market failure is responsible for the lack of finance going into small enterprises and into infrastructure projects; and that this market failure is somehow the fault of those dreadful conservative fund managers who are doing such villainous things as trying to protect our precious savings by investing in safe investments, such as blue chip equities or the bond market—although in the last two years the bond market has resembled a Quentin Tarantino movie in the sense that there has been blood everywhere. Last year, for example—and I will not seek the leave of the House to incorporate my table of the bond futures market—

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is grateful.

—I am glad to hear it. I might seek to do it one day if I am in a poor mood. I might point out that early in 1994 the bond futures stood at 93; by the end of last year, they were down to 89.3, which took them well over 10 per cent. I am sure that many of the members of this House have had the same experience that I have had; that is, having constituents coming into the office to complain about the dreadful returns of their superannuation funds. That is probably largely what is behind some of the diminishing confidence that has appeared in the surveys conducted by various consumers organisations and the ASFA, to which the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) referred in his speech. But, putting that aside, I will perhaps leave Quentin Tarantino and other things for another time.

PARA.TAB: However, I go back to the notion that somehow the market is failing to deliver finance to small enterprises which would, in turn, create the exports that we so dearly need to repair our awful trade balance. I say that is a ridiculous notion because, since the 1970s, for example, many of the policies of governments, especially governments of the Labor variety, have rendered Australian small enterprises as vastly less attractive investments than their alternatives, being those that are listed on the stock exchange or in the bond market—and certainly less attractive these days than investments you will find in our region but outside of Australia. New Zealand is a good example; the reforms which have taken place there have rendered investment in a small enterprise far more attractive than those in Australia.

Plainly, it does not seem to have occurred to the Prime Minister or Mr Kelty that these days a small business, which is presumably the destination for much of this venture capital, can be wiped out almost instantly by a contrived unfair dismissal claim or a malevolent ruling from the Taxation Office. We have to ask: why would a sane investor risk his or her precious capital investing in a higher risk enterprise, operating in a political and regulatory environment that is just plainly anti-business?

Simply put, the problem is not really top down in that there is something wrong with the fund managers who are in charge of these enormous funds and who are making the decisions not to invest in these projects. The problem really is bottom up in that there is something flawed; something is inhibiting the returns that such a guardian of our capital would require before he or she would make such an investment. That is going back to first principles, which require of us that we ask two or three pertinent questions.

First, we have to ask: is capital potentially available for these projects? I think the answer is plainly yes. In this borderless world, it is possible for an Eskimo in Alaska to invest in a venture capital fund which is dedicated to investments in Australia if he wants to. There is nothing to stop him going in to see a broker in Anchorage and making a decision, after studying the investment environment, and doing exactly that. In the capital markets, more so than any other sector of our economy, resources will move from one part of the world to the other with a speed that has never been seen before.

It is about saying that she has a recollection different from other ministers or that she is a liar—this when the Liberal Party have raised untruthfulness in the parliament to an art form over the years, and recently. The member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) sits up the back in clear testimony of the truth of that statement.

I wonder if we had a royal commission about what John Howard knew about the question to the minister for Aboriginal affairs, whether he encouraged the member for Barker to put the question which he knew was predicated on a lie and an untruth, how he would do as a goody-two-shoes before a royal commission. You see some of these dreadful things in other countries, and it is said, `Well, it couldn't happen here.' Well, it is happening here. It is happening here because of a bankrupt, immoral government in Western Australia which has dishonestly crafted terms of reference to protect itself, to compound its dishonesty, to try to fit up a political opponent as the cause of a woman's death. That is what is on here.

So let me say on this side of the House that the royal commission's terms of reference do not go to the woman's death. The commissioner makes that completely clear. We on this side of the House accept the things which Barbara Campbell and Ian Taylor and others have said, that there is no connection between the petition and her death. We accept that. We accept those points.

Therefore, if the petition is only about sitting in some narrow discussion about what ministers can remember from years ago, wouldn't that be a great little sport if we went around the parliaments of the states and the Commonwealth saying what ministers can remember from years ago and what people did under certain circumstances? That is why the kangaroo court has no place in Australian politics, no place in Australian civil life. But what has a place here is morality and decency. If the Liberal Party want to say that Carmen Lawrence was the cause of Penny Easton's death, let them make the substantive motion, not slink in here under the privilege of parliament for cowards, like the members for Mackellar and O'Connor, to make the charge against her.

Let it be understood: the man responsible for this tactic is the Leader of the Opposition. He condones it. It is his immorality. It is his Liberal Party. In putting that statement out today, he makes a mockery of his own statement by letting the member for O'Connor mock him in the parliament after he has made his statement and his order against him. Opposition members interjecting—

—The government over the past few weeks has done everything it possibly can to prevent the truth coming out—

PARA.TAB: In a nutshell, what the Prime Minister is really saying is that, because the royal commission is not investigating the circumstances of Penny Easton's death, the royal commission is of no relevance and of no account. It doesn't matter what Carmen Lawrence said or did. It does not matter what Keith Wilson or Pam Beggs said or did. None of those things are of any relevance.

What the government has done over the last couple of months is set about to deliberately devalue the notion that ministers ought to tell the truth. That is what they have tried to do. The Australian public—through all of the bluster and through all of those sitting in dumb silence on the back bench of the Labor Party while their own leader was speaking—has to understand that you are, lemming-like, being led over the cliff towards a situation where, if this royal commission brings down an adverse finding against Carmen Lawrence, your leader and deputy leader are going to get up and repudiate the recommendations of the royal commission. That, basically, is what the government is setting out to do.

The government is preparing the way to reject the recommendations of the royal commission. I do not know how many people over there know that that is its course of action. TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was rudely interrupted by that storm of falsehood and malice, I was making some remarks about the dangerous notion of directed investment, concerning a falsity doing the rounds of the financial media regarding the possible use of superannuation funds to fund venture capital, developmental capital or infrastructure projects.

PARA.TAB: The point I was trying to make was that this notion of market failure being attributed to fund managers was quite false and that fund managers should be left to do their job according to the covenants contained in section 52 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, which is the parent act of the legislation which we are seeking to amend today. I expect that debate to continue for some months. I will do my best to participate in the debate in the media, to quash this notion that in some way a government's advice or direction to a superannuation fund manager is inherently superior to the judgments that that fund manager might make according to the quality of investment opportunities presented to him or her.

Generally speaking, the impression among the electors with whom I have discussed superannuation is that it is too complicated. The member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in his remarks earlier today made the same point—that it is very difficult to imagine public enthusiasm, which is perhaps even more important than public confidence, in superannuation, and it is very difficult to see public enthusiasm growing in an environment where things are just too complicated to possibly understand.

I recall with some dismay the remarks of Dr FitzGerald when he addressed a conference sponsored by the Australian Superannuation Funds Association in June this year at the Hyatt Hotel in Canberra. He described the superannuation regime as resembling a Sony music machine: it looked very slick and very attractive on the outside, but inside it was fiendishly complicated and, therefore, any investigation as to what was going on inside the machine should simply be left to experts.

If it is permitted for legislatures and governments to create a regime for superannuation that is so ferociously complicated that the ordinary citizens, whose funds are the subject of these laws, are not even permitted implicitly to investigate and understand it for themselves, then where are we ever going to generate the enthusiasm that is required beyond what exists now? One glance or one small exposure to the nomenclature of superannuation, with terms such as `transferable RBLs' and so forth, makes it quite plain that, so long as we fail in our efforts to somehow simplify this system and make it a bit more user friendly—to use a popular term these days—the notion of thrift will really not take hold with as much success as it is necessary to achieve.

Supervision of superannuation, as it is conducted in this country, is plainly a requirement of generating that needed public confidence. Just as the member for Curtin, who is in the chair now, has described some of the woes that his constituents have brought to him, I can say that I have experienced exactly the same thing in my short time as the member for Wentworth. Two weeks ago, a lady came in to see me. A resident of Perth, she had made the decision to move to Sydney—laudable though that is—but had left behind in a Perth superannuation fund some $80,000.

After working for a short time in Sydney, she consulted a financial intermediary who advised her that the best thing she could do was to roll over the money and transfer it to a fund in New South Wales, where she could have much closer access to the fund managers who were investing it for her. She signed a rollover authority, giving that financial intermediary authority to direct the fund in Western Australia to transfer the money via a bank—the Commonwealth Bank, as a matter of fact—to a fund in New South Wales, in Sydney.

Somehow or other—and this is not clear—the intermediary used that authority to persuade an officer of the bank in Perth to transfer that money via telegraphic transfer to his own bank account, giving the impression that he was acting as her agent and that he had her authority. Sadly, he misappropriated those funds to satisfy his own personal debts.

SPEECH.PARA: Shortly thereafter, he was detected and charged with a variety of fraudulent acts and, of course, a bankruptcy petition was lodged against him. Westpac, which was his bank, appropriated the money in his account to satisfy outstanding debts that he had with it. Result? Dr R's money vanished.

PARA.TAB: She went to the ISC, the commissioner, whose budget apparently we are dealing with today. If this late lodgment levy we are talking about is some sort of user-pays scheme for approved funds to fund the cost of supervision, then we are talking about the commissioner's role in the scheme of superannuation. I wonder whether you can guess what the answer was from the commissioner? `No, it is a bank problem. It is not a super problem. It was the bank that transferred the money from itself in Perth to another bank in New South Wales. I am sorry. It is not a superannuation problem. Go and see the bank ombudsman.'

Taking advice from this commissioner and believing it, Dr R went to see the bank ombudsman. Guess what he said? `It is a super problem, not a bank problem. It was from a super fund. The authority you signed for this villain was an authority to roll over your super money, so go and see the commissioner.' Result? She went to see her MP.

When I heard this, early in my career, I thought, `Well, this is how government works these days, isn't it?' You set up a commission, you set up an ombudsman, you fund them, you give them cars, you see them flying between the capitals of this country, bolstering the airlines' profits. And what do they do? They write letters to our constituents saying, `Oh, no, it's not us. Go and see our brethren down the road.' No help at all.

This woman, who is practising as a psychologist in Paddington but living in my electorate, is now impecunious. She cannot afford the legal fees that you can imagine she would incur if she took on Westpac. We have all had people in our offices who are victims of various acts of misunderstanding or villainy by banks. There are not a few of them in the country. The prospect of challenging them in the courts is fanciful,

The undertaking I gave to her was to seek the help of a large Sydney law firm which was prepared to act for her on a pro bono basis. It was only a couple of days before I headed back down here that a nice bureaucratic form turned up in my office, an application for pro bono work to be done, via the Law Institute. I will do my very best to see that she gets that service because, by God, she deserves it, the commissioner having done absolutely nothing to help her.

Where money accumulates, it is sad to say, so will villains accumulate, so will people whose standards of honesty and integrity do not measure up to those prescribed in the legislation. It is important that, whilst we try not to overcomplicate the process of regulation, and certainly of establishing and operating super funds, we make sure that the public is satisfied that acts of imprudent management and imprudent investment are the subject of some sort of action in the legislation we consider in this place.

In that respect it is as well to recall the trouble that occurred in the bond markets last year. I have had a few people come into my office with documents saying that they had invested in a capital stable fund. What does that mean to the ordinary person in the street? It means that the principal stays at what it was when you invested it and that you accrue interest as time passes—nothing too risky. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the international campaign to ban landmines. The Australian Land Mines Network is planning a national day of awareness on 28 August to heighten awareness of the landmines crisis. Over 80 organisations will be participating in this national day of action. In Sydney, prominent Australians such as Gabi Hollows, Justice Marcus Einfeld and representatives of bodies of the Catholic Church will urge the Australian government to support the ban on the use, trade, production and stockpiling of anti-personnel mines.

PARA.TAB: There are over 100 million landmines laid in more than 60 countries, killing over 10,000 civilians each year. According to UNICEF, between 30 to 40 per cent of landmine victims are children. While the United Nations and countries including Austria, Belgium, Cambodia and Sweden have thrown their weight behind this global ban, Australia maintains that landmines are a legitimate weapon in terms of defensive warfare. I would argue that we do not make these weapons in this country. We do not have a use for them, not since the Vietnam war. I would argue that we strongly support the ban.

While the Australian government has provided assistance for mine clearance operation, it only supports a ban on landmines that do not have a self-destruct or self-neutralisation capacity. There are arguments that landmines are a military necessity. The long-term human and socioeconomic costs far outweigh any short-term military utility. Chemical weapons have been said by some to be useful in times of war also, but their impact on human beings has been so devastating that they have been banned. Landmines must also go into that category because they are uncontrollable and they are an indiscriminate sort of weapon whose eventual target cannot be determined by the military and is more likely to be a civilian.

The truth is that self-destruct and self-neutralising mines are not reliable. It is difficult to obtain an accurate figure of their failure rate. Certainly, a meeting of experts called the International Committee of the Red Cross suggests at least 10 per cent is a realistic failure rate. That failure rate means that any area mined with smart mines will have to be cleared just as carefully as an area covered with conventional mines.

Many of the poorer countries in the developing world will oppose a ban on anti-personnel mines unless smart mines, at least, are included. This is because smart mines are far more expensive to buy and the richer countries would be in control of supply, make a profit and have easier access to these weapons.

In terms of recent international moves, Belgium has enacted legislation for a total ban on the production of stockpiling transfer and the use of anti-personnel landmines; such legislation is to be reviewed within five years. A moratorium on export of anti-personnel mines is to be placed in 15 states including Canada, France, Great Britain, South Africa and the United States of America. Italy has a moratorium on production in Italian territory. The United States Senate has voted for an amendment which would place a moratorium on the use and deployment of landmines after a three-year period for the US army to test and deploy alternative tactics and weapons.

States which have declared support for a total ban include Belgium, Sweden, Mexico, Italy, Ireland, Cambodia, Switzerland, Afghanistan and Estonia. Even more importnat is that countries see a ban as a desirable goal. Australia, unfortunately, has not yet declared its support. More African states will attend a review conference and 13 countries have indicated their support for the total ban. Certainly what needs to be done is a twofold approach—that is, the clearing of mines in place at present and a commitment of funds to the research and the development of mine clearance technology and a total ban on the production, use, transfer, export, sale and stockpiling of anti-personnel landmines.
I conclude with a quote from Ken Done, who has been very supportive as an UNICEF goodwill ambassador. I was on the board of UNICEF for seven years and am a life member. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: I urge all Australians to support the efforts of the International Campaign to Ban Landmines to achieve a total ban of their production, sale, marketing, export and use on this National Day of Action. Landmines pose one of the most serious risks to the safety and well-being of millions of people around the world. At present some 100 million landmines are in place and another 100 million mines lie in stockpiles ready for use. Children are particularly vulnerable because of their natural curiosity. Landmines come in a bewildering array of shapes and colours. The sheer number of them in some countries leads children to regard them as harmless, every day objects. The cruelty of these weapons and their growing cost in human and economic terms is a catastrophe. They must be banned entirely and as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 November last year I raised in the House, in the context of debate on the Racial Hatred Bill 1994, my concerns about an incident that had occurred at a company in Brisbane involving some Spanish speaking workers, originating in particular from El Salvador. Those workers were on strike as a result of discriminatory behaviour that had occurred at their workplace, Steel-Line Doors, and as a number of them had been subjected to violence, intimidation, harassment and injury, with all of those incidents being racially based. On that previous occasion, I outlined to the House my concern about this incident and the fact that it was a poor situation to have occurred in Australia—as it is in contrast to the normally very good race relations which occur in this country.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to be able to outline to the House that after many months there has been a settlement to this dispute and, in fact, the workers' position has been vindicated in that settlement. A few days ago, in early August, the management of Steel-Line Doors reached an agreement with the workers and their legal representatives, through the Anti-Discrimination Tribunal, in a hearing in front of the President of the Queensland Anti-Discrimination Tribunal, Ms R. Atkinson. This resolution and settlement has totally and completely vindicated the workers position on this matter—and I am pleased that that has occurred.

It has been a very long period for these workers. They have been on strike and, therefore, without income for some eight or nine months. They have all had many struggles. They escaped their homeland and come to this country as refugee immigrants. In doing so, all personal resources, all personal belongings which had been accumulated over the years had to be left behind. They were living in rental accommodation and had suffered greatly from their experiences in their former homeland—and it was an enormous tragedy that these workers also had to suffer such racial discrimination after having arrived in this country.

Thankfully, the justice system in this country has vindicated their position, and they have received a settlement which is in their favour. In fact, their settlement is the largest settlement to have been arrived at against a company or corporation in Queensland by the Anti-Discrimination Commission. The settlement involves the company making a payment to the workers of the sum of $85,000, such sum to be distributed amongst the complainants as they choose. It roughly works out at a payment per person of about $5,000.

The company will ensure that enterprise bargaining agreements, when finalised, shall include dispute handling procedures for complaints of discrimination. The company will also ensure that those workers who choose not to return to their employment at Steel-Line Doors—and, Mr Speaker, you can imagine that a lot of them do not wish to—will get Department of Social Security separation certificates. Also, the company management is required to publish an apology to the workers for the upset and hurt that they have suffered as a result of the practices that were engaged in by the management and other workers of that company.

They will also be receiving, as a result of this settlement, all of their holiday pay entitlement that they had accrued up until the moment they went on strike, plus an additional 1 1/2 weeks pay. It is not a large amount of money for every individual worker. It works out around $6,500 per worker, but that is not what they were on about. They were seeking justice for their claims of discrimination and victimisation, and I am pleased that that has been achieved.

My congratulations go, firstly, to the workers for their determination and their grit through this very painful process and to the leader of the group, George Rodriguez. Secondly, I wish to express my sincere congratulations to the men's lawyer, Mr Joe Teixeira, who has done an outstanding job in representing their case and in ensuring that these workers did receive justice in the end. I am pleased that we have been able to achieve a settlement, even though it did take so many months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to note briefly tonight the death some three weeks ago of Sir Bernard Callinan. As many members in this place will be aware, Bernard Callinan was the Chairman of the Parliament House Construction Authority between 1979 and 1985. It is therefore appropriate that there be some record in the Hansard of this place of his passing.

PARA.TAB: I did not know Sir Bernard Callinan in that capacity, but I did know him in other capacities. His contribution to this country, not simply as the Chairman of the Parliament House Construction Authority but in a whole range of endeavours, was remarkable.

It is also particularly appropriate, as Australia has just recently celebrated the 50th anniversary of the end of the Second World War during the Australia Remembers week, that we speak of Bernard Callinan, because he was the leader of the Australian Independent Company—that small group of about 300 Australian soldiers who, after the Japanese invasion of Portuguese-Timor as it then was in 1942, remained there for some considerable time as a commando unit and, according to many assessments, may well have had a significant impact in the course of the Second World War against the Japanese.
In the introductory chapter to Bernard Callinan's book about those days, entitled Independent Company: The Australian Army and Portuguese-Timor 1941-1943, Nevil Shute wrote this about that effort:

The Australian Commandos never secured a prisoner, though they tried to get one once or twice, and they never succeeded in preventing the Japanese from doing anything that they really wanted to do. They killed about fifteen hundred of the enemy for the loss of forty of their own men. They stood and fought when practically every other unit in the Far East was forced to surrender; they evacuated in good order and became operational again as a detachment in New Guinea.

They were one of three small forces which between them immobilised two Japanese divisions. At sea, the American submarines were operating from Fremantle against Japanese shipping with increasing success, and in the air the squadrons of the American and Australian Air Forces were operating from airfields in the Northern Territory with increasing strength. These activities, with those of the Australian Commandos in Timor, convinced the Japanese High Command that a counter offensive from Australia was in preparation. Accordingly they sent their 48th division to Timor to reinforce the existing garrison; this was an experienced division of fifteen thousand men which had served in China, the Philippines, and Java. The same anxiety later caused them to send their 5th Division, which had fought in Malaya, to the Ambon and western New Guinea area, and to form from these divisions a new army with headquarters on Ceram Island. These three small, valiant efforts on the land, the sea, and in the air, immobilised over thirty thousand Japanese troops, at what was possibly the worst time in the war for the Allies.
Few soldiers in history can claim to have done more than that.

SPEECH.PARA: So if Bernard Callinan's contribution and that of his men was just in the defence of Australia then he and those other members of the Independent Company should stand in the history books and the record books of this country for a long time.

PARA.TAB: Bernard Callinan served Australia in many other ways, so numerous that there would be too many to list in the time available to me tonight. He was President of the Royal Humane Society. He was Chairman of the National Catholic Education Commission. He was a commissioner of the ABC, a commissioner of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, a counsellor at the University of Melbourne and Deputy Chancellor of La Trobe University, amongst a whole range of other appointments.

In 1980 Bernard Callinan delivered the Mannix lecture on that other great engineer, Sir John Monash. Towards the conclusion of his lecture he said these words about Monash which I think can equally apply to Callinan himself:

SPEECH.PARA: If genius is the extraordinary use of extraordinary gifts, and greatness the extraordinary use of ordinary gifts, Monash can truly be described as great. He achieved greatness essentially as an administrator, by the cultivation to a high pitch of excellence his great array of talents and virtues: a fine memory, attention to detail, energy, capacity for hard work, concentration, orderliness, commonsense and fine judgment; all joined with a temperament and constitution that enabled him to work harmoniously with colleagues, and to stand the `heat in the kitchen'. Certainly, he was a great leader.
I do not know whether Callinan was a great leader, but he was certainly a loyal and committed Australian who contributed in a very great way to this nation.
